div.p: The research reported in this work provides one of the first empirical examinations of politically successful Public/Private Partnership In Education. As such, this research builds a theoretical model of political success and then empirically tests it against data from a national survey. In building and testing this model, this work employs a mixed research program of qualitative and quantitative methodologies. In-depth telephone interviews with select stakeholders from two case study cities build the context of the work and lead to the development and clarification of the relevant research concepts. These qualitative data are supported with quantitative data collected via a mail survey from a national sample of stakeholders participating in Public/Private Partnerships In Education. These survey data are subjected to a Structural Equation Model (SEM) path analysis based on multivariate regression techniques. The findings support many of the hypothesized pathways and demonstrate the importance of goal formation, goal attainment, and leadership to the success of partnerships in education. As one of the first empirical models of partnership success coming from the policy sciences, this work contributes to the literature by combining the elements of theoretical abstraction with empirical rigor.
This research concludes with implications drawn from the findings and then makes some recommendations for future work.

Over two decades ago, the U.S. Housing and Urban Development's (U.S. HUD, 1980) Urban Land Institute projected that public/private partnerships would use public and private resources to their fullest advantage by gaining the involvement of the business community, foundations, other private entities, and federal agencies (p. 20). In addition, this type of leveraging was not projected to be isolated to any one specific activity, nor at any single level of government. As the report stated: Judging from recent events, higher levels of public/private activity can be projected for the coming decade. For example, major business communities at the local level…have begun to…work closely with municipal, state, and federal agencies. Long established downtown business promotion organizations have become sophisticated in the areas of housing, public education, and crime abatement (HUD, 1980, p. 5).

In the 1990s, the term partnership became almost synonymous with many functions of public education. As the role and scope of business and industry involvement in public education has grown, the diversity level of activities has also grown. Jacqueline Danzberger, writing for the U.S. Department of Education, Office of Educational Research and Improvement, states:

Over the last several years, educational partnerships have proliferated across the country. Some have developed in response to legislation. Others have become vehicles for fundamental educational reform. Still others have delivered services to students and faculty to improve education or student outcomes, whether or not schools are attempting systemic changes. Partners undertaking joint endeavors with schools also vary greatly. Partnership relationships are built among schools and social service agencies, cultural institutions, businesses, industries, and institutions of higher education (Danzberger, 1998).

Along with these high levels of partnership activity, administrators, practitioners, and scholars have kept pace by documenting, categorizing, and, most recently, evaluating various forms of Public/Private Partnerships in Education. In fact, for more than twenty years a body of literature has been accumulating on partnerships in education. According to Callahan (1995) this literature is comprised of articles and studies that: i. Provide guidance on how to establish partnerships ii. Discusses the most common categories and types of partnerships iii. Showcases individual partnerships that are particularly successful, and iv. Address the issue of monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of various partnerships (Callahan, p. 1).
Clearly, partnerships have become the subjects of interest to a large and diverse audience.

Indeed, the interest level is so high that the federal government has taken a strong lead in This act created The Educational Partnerships Program (EPP) which: …stimulated the creation of educational partnerships to demonstrate their contribution to educational reform. The EPP was administered by the Educational Networks Division, Programs for the Improvement of Practice, Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI). The authorizing legislation required documenting the partnerships that received assistance, assessing their impact on educational institutions, evaluating the extent to which they improved their communities' climate for support of education, and identifying promising activities (http//www.ed.gov/pubs/Partners/case2.html/August 14, 1998).

In addition to funding partnership activity, the Federal government publishes numerous documents aimed at helping stakeholders formulate and implement Public/Private Partnerships in Education. One such document (http://www.ed.gov/pubs/PromPract/prom2.html) is of particular interest to this research. It outlines a set of guidelines for building partnerships and details a common set of activities typical of partnerships in education. This work is representative of much of the literature in Public/Private Partnerships in Education and demonstrates two weaknesses in this growing field. Although these weaknesses are different in their application, at their core is a common reference point that serves as the foundation of this research. This focus is the notion of partnership success.

Thus, the first weakness in the partnership literature is a lack of theoretical sophistication in building a formal model of success. There are many works that detail the "hows" of partnerships (Danzberger and Gruskin, 1993;Grobe, 1993;Rigden, 1991), but they fail to sufficiently tie their enumerations to a solid theoretical foundation. Similarly, researchers (Danzberg and Gruskin, 1993;Otterbourg, 1990;Tushnet, 1993) have recently become concerned with the rigorous evaluation of partnerships, however, the evaluation emphasis has been on educational outcomes and/or the partnership process, rather than on the success of the process. The critical assumption of this research is that this focus on outcomes and process in evaluation is an inherent weakness in being able to fully understand the dynamic of partnerships ---and partnership making.
This research is designed to fill the gap in the literature left by these two weaknesses by building a model of partnership success. In this effort, the following format will be followed.

Following this brief introduction, a history of Public/Private Partnerships in Education will be detailed. The goals of this research will then be presented, put into context, and the limitations addressed. To conclude this introductory section, the purpose of the study will be formalized and the research questions enumerated.
A review of the literature will then be offered to build the context and scope of the field.
Following the literature review, the methodology employed in data collection will be discussed.
Next, the findings from the data analysis will be presented for consideration, and finally concluding remarks will be made. To begin, then, a brief history is now presented.

div.head: History Of Public/Private Partnerships (in Education)
div.p: The history of public/private partnerships is by no means restricted to the field of education. Public/private partnerships have existed for three decades in housing, crime prevention, local economic development, and in the provision of social services. However, since the early 1980s heavy resources have been committed to improving and increasing the number of partnerships targeting economic development, social services and education. In addition, education has often been implicitly addressed via targeted opportunities in economic development and the social services. More recently, this implicit linkage has been brought to the forefront of discussions addressing serious urban problems. Indeed, at a recent Ohio Urban University Program (UUP, 1998) conference the argument was made, and supporting data presented, that many of the social barriers to the economic revitalization of (Ohio's) urban regions are directly linked to public education and the lack of a skilled work force.

Although there are a great number of, and a large variation in, the specific reasons for targeting education, in their basic foundation most reasons can be identified to fit into one of two categories. Hence, to some stakeholders, a skilled work force is a mandatory factor of production in an efficient economy. The education and training of students makes business competitive in a global economy and, after all, paraphrasing the famous quote, "what's good for business and industry is good for the country." Similarly, others view education as a means to insure a healthy democratic society. Through education, children are socialized into political participation and become informed about the issues. Even though, beginning in the 1980s, the emphasis has shifted to favor the former rationale; this work makes no normative claims about the various motivations for participation in Public/Private Partnerships in Education.

These claims and interests in education are by no means new. Throughout our nation's history, business has often taken an active role in public education. Business has been linked to education since the late 1800s, as rapid industrial change required education to meet the needs of the work force through the creation of new programs and institutions (Grobe, 1993, p. 3). This involvement grew as business took a more active role in public education. As Timpane notes "For the first half of this century, industry in America was a strong force behind the movement for universal schooling and for vocational education (Timpane, 1991, p. 1)." School boards around the nation in communities of all sizes were predominantly comprised of local businessmen. In addition, civic clubs hosted events and charity drives to help out their local schools. However, this interest started to wane in the 1960s and had all but disappeared from the public education scene by the 1970s (Timpane, 1991). There were several reasons for why this withdrawal from public education occurred.

As the costs associated with participation in public school systems increased, business involvement declined through the 1960s and 1970s. As new stakeholders came to the forefront to address issues of equity and due process in public education, power shifted from school boards, traditionally comprised of individuals from business, to teacher organizations, community groups, advocates, and state and federal judges. Business people withdrew from deliberations concerning issues of bussing, desegregation, and school violence; issues which were new and frustrating to business people. As business interests withdrew, their influence over educators, and the public education process, dissipated (Timpane, 1991, p.1). However, as these problems started to impact society in general, and the labor market specifically, business was forced to take another look at public education.

From 1980 to 1990 "…the number of high school graduates would decline by 20 percent… (Timpane, 1991, p. 3)." This decline was a symptom of a more serious problem endemic to the economy. Not only was the labor pool shrinking, but the percent of qualified workers, those with basic technical skills, was also decreasing. Business was faced with supply side labor problems at the same time the economy was growing and global competition was increasing. According to Timpane (1991) it was these supply side pressures, more than any other factor, that led to a renewed interest in public schools on the part of business (Timpane, 1991, p. 3).

Business started coming back into the fold in the early 1980s as education once again took the forefront of the national agenda with heavy hits from reports like "A Nation At Risk" (1983). This report, published by the U.S. Department of Education's National Commission on Excellence in Education, showed the critical need for reform in public education. In addition, federal policy was not sufficient to handle the crisis and state and local governments were even less prepared. It was an opportune time for business to step back into the arena.

Nationally, business was quick and deliberate in once again showing an interest in public education. One report shows that "Between 1983-84 and 1987-88, the number of business/education partnerships rose from 42,200 to 140,800. More than 9 million students ---24 percent of public school students ---were directly involved in education partnerships (Grobe, 1993, p. 4)." This great call-to-arms however, did not produce uniform activities, nor did it guarantee systemic change, improved performance, continued involvement, or partnership success.
This discussion now turns to types of partnership activity that exists and begins laying the context for the process of detailing a model of partnership success.
The business agenda of the 1980s produced three types of education initiatives:
(1) improving educational quality by raising standards for students, teachers, and schools and focusing on accountability;

(2) restructuring schools as places of work and teaching as a profession; and most recently (3) focusing on the educational and social service needs of at-risk children through the provision of early childhood programs and greater coordination between educational and social services (Timpane, 1991, p. X).

There is also a large degree of diversity in how business and education go about implementing those initiatives, and the levels of involvement that exists. According to Timpane, (1991) there are four stages of business involvement. At the most fundamental level there are helping-hand relationships where business provides tangible goods and services, followed by programmatic initiatives in which business attempts to change one building or a specific program. Moving towards more complex involvement, there are compacts and collaborative efforts are where business provides a community wide umbrella for a wide range of schoolbusiness and school-community activities and pressure for district wide reforms. The most involved type of relationship is the policy change relationship where business leaders and organizations are active participants in developing a vast array of new policies, especially at the state level (Timpane, 1991, p. 9).

Through these initiatives and their various levels of associated involvement, business and industry's educational partnerships have evolved over time to meet the changing needs of not only education, but also society as a whole. In a document prepared for the Educational Partnerships Study Group, Education Resources Group (ERG, 1991) suggests that alliances may be formed for four basic purposes:

1. to apply the resources of the private and nonprofit sectors of the community to the needs of the elementary and secondary schools or the institutions of higher education in that community to encourage excellence in education;

2. to encourage businesses to work with educationally disadvantaged students and with gifted students; 3. to apply the resources of communities for the improvement of elementary and secondary education or higher education; and 4. to enrich the career awareness of secondary or post-secondary school students and provide exposures to the work of the private sector (ERG, 1991, p. 2).
Furthermore, of the 18 projects ERG (1991) considered when recommending evaluation options, the following characteristics were highlighted in their report:

• Half the projects will be carried out at the school level, including one that is statewide and one that is regional in scope. • Levels of schooling addressed by the project are mixed. For example, while five are at the secondary school level, four cover k to 12. • The variety of partners is rich: five projects include the private, university, community, and parents sectors, four involve businesses primarily, and the remaining half include one or two of these sectors. • Eight projects target disadvantaged, at-risk students, and four will work with both at-risk and gifted students. Six will serve 'all' students in the school, district, or state. • Half the projects will focus on career awareness/work experience activities. Ten plan some form of staff development. Eleven will include tutoring, mentoring, internships, and/or volunteer work. (These were key program purposes or recommended activities). • About a third are focusing on math/science and/or technology as a theme (ERG, 1991, p. 4).

Given the complexity and diversity of Public/Private Partnerships in Education, and the aforementioned weaknesses in the corresponding literature, the task of this research becomes one of building a model of partnership success that is capable of generalizing across multiple dimensions. To this end, this discussion now turns to detailing an intellectual framework of analysis and describing where this research fits with existing knowledge.
Hence, this work fits thematically with Otterbourg's (1986) work of over 14 years ago and it accepts the importance of expectations and her reasons for supporting partnerships as axiomatic.

Otterbourg (1986) writes about the support that partnerships bring to the educational environment: "Partnerships will not pay for teachers or maintenance of buildings. However, alliances can stimulate and support staff development, enrichment programs, basic skills projects…and many other programmatic efforts…(p. 3)." Another reason to support partnerships is the development of "Political Allies" that "…can prove to be formidable [support in counteracting] negativism and criticism…(p. 4)." It is within the realm of these two critical political arenas that this work is developed. The politics of forming, implementing and sustaining Public/Private Partnerships in Education is more critical today than in 1986.

In support of stressing the importance of political viability, over outcomes or process, as a research goal, Timpane (1991) has articulated that an important emphasis of business involvement should be to continue its involvement. "It has taken a decade for business communities ---local, state, and national ---to arrive at a stable, comprehensive view of the problems they and education face and the roles they can play in improving the schools (Timpane, 1991, p. 35)."

But the level of business and education involvement in a specific partnership, and the degree to which that partnership addresses a variety of social problems are critical factors that must be addressed. Thus, although the number of partnerships across the country have grown over time, and the use of the term partnership is being used much more than it was twenty years ago, the level of understanding of the true relevance and importance of partnerships has not grown accordingly.

Where the term partnership was once used sparingly, and authors struggled to define it, a task that was never quite achieved, it now seems as though every form of collaboration, sharing of resources and division of power is labeled a "partnership." However, this work gives a very specific meaning to the concept of partnership and relates why true partnerships in education are of vital importance to the educational system, and, indeed, the country. This detailed definition, and its relevance to this research will be addressed in greater detail in the literature review section of this work. At this point, however, the task is to articulate some comments about partnerships in general to demonstrate the importance of this research.

As an important caveat to this work, it must be clearly stated that there are many forms and degrees of partnering that are ongoing across the country. This research is concerned with all types, degrees, and systemic levels in building a general model of success, but it does reflect an implicit value assumption. Thus, this research is more concerned about partnerships that attempt to make systemic changes in the educational environment, rather than providing mere token resources, i.e. equipment, after school experiences, and teacher externships, to single buildings.

In addition, the underlying assumption is that, in the current sociopolitical climate, partnerships that take a broad view of their environment are more likely to address systemic problems. Many partnerships only address Vo-Tech or School-To-Work issues while broader social problems plague their community. Problems like teen pregnancy; drug use; child neglect and abuse; adult illiteracy; hunger and housing are all issues that must be addressed by partnerships if true change is ever to occur.

It is almost impossible for schools to educate children when faced with such problems. However, it is not just the educators who are limited by facing these troubling issues, but it is also the limited ability of the children living in crisis. As one national report argued:

The deeply troubling circumstances of many children's lives limit their ability to learn…[problems that must be dealt with include]…poverty, neglect, child abuse, racism, drug and alcohol abuse, depression, and teen pregnancy-before any real teaching can take place (National Education Association, 1985, p. 1).
At this stage of partnership efficacy, the horse must remain in front of the cart. Partnerships must be formed and maintained while bringing about systemic change.

There are two arguments that must now be delineated. The first is that through defining partnership success in political terms, i.e., viability, the horse stays in front of the cart. Second, that partnerships are needed to ultimately increase the chances of achieving desired educational outcomes. The latter argument will be addressed first.

In the current political and economic environment, it is almost impossible for a local public school district to singularly marshal enough resources to bring about systemic changes. As Timpane (1991) points out, even when business becomes involved, it is sometimes not enough.
He states: "Business projects in local schools still vary widely in scope and effect and often barely address, let alone provide, needed improvements in the larger educational system (p. X)."

Yet it is also true that irrespective of the level of involvement, local schools increase their chances of improving social conditions when they have the additional resources provided by a business partner. To phrase it more succinctly: …the school system alone cannot meet the differing needs of all of its students…. The parents themselves must be active participants; and the school system and other community agencies---the churches and social service organizations---must provide the support that will facilitate such involvement (National Education Association, 1985, p. 13).

Garnering such support is never easy, nor without political upheaval. Writing about marshalling community support for public schools, Estes (1974) acknowledges that: "Local control and a democratic, pluralistic society are a precious heritage, but they entail by definition controversy, noise, and change (Estes, 1974, p. 25)." However, there is past experience to drawn upon in managing the inherent political conflict. The federal government publishes a "lessons learned" list based on a series of case studies. These lessons are:
• Outside funding stimulates action.

• Each participating organization is challenged to change policies and procedures to accommodate a new way of working with others. • Partnership approaches require adaptation to fit each community, school district, and school. • Organizational mavericks may be a source of creative and meaningful programs, but they need support to strengthen and improve the program. • A shared vision and deep commitment among partners can overcome weaknesses in program design and implementation. • Even with confusion about how the partnership structure relates to the program, the partnership itself can be institutionalized. • Leadership is critical in a complex partnership.

• Leaders who reflect commitment to particular programs and processes may be more successful than leaders who see themselves as facilitators. • Identifying and solving problems, using adaptive planning, contributes to success. • Skilled and committed staff empowered to carry out partnership plans are an important element in project success. • A complex partnership can be strengthened by breaking it down into components. • University students are a valuable resource for classroom teachers, even if the students are not pre-service teachers. In addition to the aforementioned reasons, the vast number, the diversity, and the sheer complexity of public/private partnerships across the nation lead to several issues concerning evaluations of such partnerships and their respective programs. Among the many goals and programs that an evaluator of Public/Private Partnerships in Education might be concerned with addressing there are: programs targeted for at-risk youth, programs designed to increase access to work experience, providing technical assistance, generating public awareness, programs to increase participation in specific technical fields, programs to increase retention rates, and advisory panels designed to help schools and/or their entire district run more efficiently. The list is as endless as there are partnerships across the nation.

As ERG (1991) cautions "These variations limit the evaluator's opportunity to study across-the-board outcomes for students, staff, or partners. Research is needed that undertakes comparative studies of the various ways of interrelating: cooperation, coordination, collaboration, and so on. With a further delineation of the components of each process, including an explication of the costs and benefits of each, perhaps we would learn the requirements of each method, the limitations, and the effectiveness of each type under specific circumstances (1986, p. 8).

Although the comparative goal recommended by Hord is an alternative to the evaluation of specific programs created and/or implemented by particular partnerships, it is clearly a tall order and not very feasible given limited resources, fiscal constraints and the existing body of knowledge. In addition, the outcome evaluation Hord expouses concentrates on a cost/benefit analysis with successful program outcomes being the goal. This type of process evaluation also neglects the important role the political viability plays in partnerships.

Thus, a third evaluation alternative must be considered. This alternative focuses on the characteristics of successful partnerships by identifying, empirically testing and communicating the important organizational factors that lead to partnership political viability. These characteristics are as important as outcome measures and partnership process in the evaluations of partnerships and their respective programs.

The assumption is that an "outcome" of a partnership is a program, and whether or not the program is a success may be measured through the outcome of that specific program, not the overall partnership. What programmatic outcomes truly measure are the success of particular programs, not the success of partnerships. For instance, in Flint, Michigan, there were numerous programs offered by the Flint Roundtable partnership. If one of these programs failed to achieve its goal, say reducing teenage pregnancy rates, would that mean the partnership was not a success? The argument made here is that the answer to this question is a decisive "no."

div.head: Limitations Of This Research
div.p: This study address the political feasibility of Public/Private Partnerships in Education.

As stated earlier, the definition of "partnership" in this work embraces the notion of shared power among the various stakeholders. As such, it intentionally ignores the specific mechanics of how different partnerships manifest themselves. The arena of public education in the early 2000s is complex with many sectors, stakeholders, programs and values making claims and contributions. There are so many types of partnerships in education, in fact, that the line between public and private education is itself becoming blurred. This research acknowledges the important role that Charter Schools, (Public) Choice, and other privatization alternatives to public education play in today's society. However, all of these alternatives rely on the building of interest groups and the sharing of resources and power. Thus, inherently all forms of non-traditional public school administration may be viewed as Public/Private Partnerships in Education.

Furthermore, as articulated early on in this work, the degree to which business is involved with public education varies dramatically across the nation. Although the size and complexity of these partnerships will have an impact on their potential success, the premise of this research is that the goal of political viability is universal. Thus, political viability, or the continued support of a partnership through continued involvement, allows the partnership time to implement processes and to achieve the desired outcomes.

The same assumption holds true for partnerships that are comprised of differing stakeholders. For this work, the term Public/Private Partnership applies not only to those partnership efforts between public education and business and industry, but also to those that involve parents, churches, governmental agencies, not-for-profit agencies, and social service agencies. An examination of each of these partnership types could easily be full research topics in and of themselves. Future work in the dynamics of various types of partnerships and detailed accounts of stakeholder involvement will eventually lead to the mass body of knowledge proposed by Hord (1986).

There are numerous research questions that are addressed by this work, but there are others that are not. This research may be considered narrow in its scope and may not be applicable to all partnership activity. However, limited resources are a key factor in any research project and this work is no exception. The research, however, does strive to maintain a high degree of rigor and identifies research topics for future work.

This work begins the process of developing the interaction-advocacy model of policy formulation and implementation. As an exploratory research project, the limitations, as outlined earlier, are due critical examination. It will only be through continued work in the theoretical and empirical fields of Public/Private Partnerships in Education that this general model of partnership success can be honed to full confirmatory status.

div.head: Purpose Of Study
div.p: The purpose of this study is to empirically examine the factors that contribute to a politically successful public/private partnership in education. Thus, a general model of success is hypothesized and then tested against data collected via a survey of partners that participate in current Public/Private Partnerships in Education. In addition to the formal tests of significance, data from a series of personal interviews will be used to support the descriptive findings of the survey. As a complete work, this research contributes to the existing body of knowledge by being empirical and quasi-confirmatory. It is labeled as such since it confirms many assumptions made about public/private partnerships (including assumptions that in the past have been considered "obvious" or "common sense") by verifying them with empirical data.
