div.head: Chapter Two: A Review Of The Relevant Literature ============ PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS IN EDUCATION ============
div.p: One of the most difficult tasks to accomplish in writing a complex thesis is the building of the context for the reader. As stated in chapter one, although this work is about public education, by default it encompasses the complexities of a cadre of social problems, and even the social construction of reality. In essence, a discussion of Public/Private Partnerships in Education is a discussion about the emergence of a new type of social organization.

One way to clarify new concepts at the cognitive level is to build a metaphor that relates old, familiar concepts to the new emergent one. In this work, an appropriate metaphor for enhancing the understanding of Public/Private Partnerships in Education is that of a community.

A community of stakeholders with a set of identifiable social relations that includes, among others, patronage and obligation. Such a social structure forms an economic and social unit which may simultaneously provide a basis for political, cultural, and, at times, even religious life. True partnerships involve stakeholders from all walks of life, and stress the interrelatedness of all social realms. Not to get lost in this metaphor requires the reader to understand the importance of the metaphor, while giving equal appreciation to the practice of partnering and partnership formation. For this work, the essential quality of the metaphor is its ability to facilitate discussion about the social system in which Public/Private Partnerships in Education operate, and how the power, inherent in the relations between the public, private, and overall communities, is distributed. Thus, society no longer clearly demarcates between social domains, and Public/Private Partnerships reflect this ambiguity in design and practice.

In the next two chapters, the most important and relevant partnership component themes are discussed and the literature examined. This discussion serves as the foundation of a theoretical model that is then tested in chapter six of this work. The order of presentation of these themes, in this chapter, are partnership power, leadership, the role of the media, the importance of stability, and why the process of achieving goals is as important as the attainment of the goals. Chapter three picks up the discussion by addressing partnerships as a new form of instrumental organization, including structural issues; the importance of clear goals to success; the roles of ideology and vision in partnering; and a general theory of partnership formation and success.

div.head: Public/Private Partnerships In Context
div.p: Recalling Otterbourg's (1986) comments cited in the introductory chapter about traditional approaches to public education not being able to meet expectations leads to this critical discussion about the importance of Public/Private Partnerships in Education. To begin, however, two observations concerning her comment must be articulated. First, improving the public education system is, and will always be, an on going process. The second observation, and for this work the more important, is that partnerships in education are about expectations. Clearly, outcomes of the educational system are important, but partnerships play a different, more symbolic role in the educational arena. If anything, partnerships in education will be of even greater importance in the new century as social and political realities dictate the sharing of resources, an increase in interdependencies, and the diversification of efforts in providing quality educational services. To insure that the aforementioned practice and experimentation continues at a level sufficient to maintain quality education, partnership viability in a complex environment becomes even more important to understand. Given this goal of viability, some very basic questions must now be addressed.

In the current atmosphere of a new Federalism, continued devolution, and the acceptability of market driven allocation, the value of public education is being questioned just as the educational system itself is being redefined by a global economy. A basic question that society must answer is why is education important? All manners of answers to this question have been postulated, but most can be categorized in one of two ways. The first type of response given is that education is an important ingredient in maintaining a skilled and qualified work force that is globally competitive. A second response is that in a free society an educated citizenry ensures a continuation of our democratic system of self-governance (Barber, 1992;Bloom, 1987;Brademas, 1987). Although these two types of responses reflect different value systems, they share a basic assumption. To summarize this assumption, "…education [is] the foundation of our hopes for building a nation strong both in economic and material terms and in the quality of our intellectual and cultural life (Brademas, 1987, p. 7)."

Liberal or conservative, market or polis orientation, all but the most extreme fringe of Americans agree that some form of public education is vital to the continued well being of our nation. Where the diversity of opinion becomes an issue is deciding how to best provide a quality education for our youth. In essence, there are two sides battling over how to achieve this goal. In one camp, there are those that feel public education has failed miserably since the mid-1960s in preparing our youth to be vital members of the work force and informed members of civil society. This camp sees the current system of public education as inefficient and ineffective, both the result of governmental largeness and, ultimately, liberal policy. To them, market forces should be tapped to bring about a greater level of efficiency and accountability in public education. One way to bring about this change is through various forms of partnerships with business and industry. These partnerships may take the form of advisory commissions/ boards, charter schools, educational vouchers, or, in the most extreme case, the privatization of schools.

The other camp is quick to defend public education, while placing the blame squarely on the shoulders of an American conservative ideology that has resulted in failed school levies and, hence, the inability of public school districts to provide quality facilities and programs. To this camp, effectiveness, not efficiency, is the issue; and to be effective requires a financial commitment from the broader community. This camp, too, looks to the development of partnerships to bring about the desired change. It is important to stress that, irrespective of ideology, both camps look to a multiplex of stakeholders to make change happen.
As the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) stresses:

Today, public/private partnerships are actively pursuing local self-reliance, and utilizing local resources with skill and creativity….We have turned away from dependence, above all else, on federal largesse. We have instead recognized once again that the true engine of economic and social progress in our society is not government, but our dynamic private sector and volunteer institutions and, that their natural partner is local, rather than federal government (U.S. HUD, 1980).

Thus, what both groups realize is that the problems facing public education are not just about the efficient allocation of resources, or the next levy up for renewal. These considerations are definitely important, but they are only a part of the broader context in which public education is struggling.

There are also the social and political "realities" of the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. Thus, in the 1970s and 1980s, as "white flight" and urban sprawl left center cities with shrinking tax bases, urban social problems created new needs for urban youth that burdened public schools even more. It became necessary for teachers to be more, and do more, than was previously expected. Teachers became de facto social workers, probation officers, family counselors, and, at times, replacement parents.

It is ironic that although there were early warnings, e.g., A Nation At Risk (National Commission on Excellence, 1983), public education did not make it to the national agenda, as a media sweetheart, until the mid-to-late 1980s. It was at this point in time that the degree and nature of the problem was discovered to be systemic, and not isolated to the urbanized center cities. The once thriving inner suburbs were loosing population to new and shinny outer suburbs; and starting to pay the social cost. Although no firm theoretical framework yet exists in the study of partnerships, there is literature that addresses the context and history of their development. For instance, Kettl (1993) argues that conservatives and liberals alike have become enthralled with partnerships based on the belief that market competition is an effective cure for inefficient and ineffective government.
In addition, Richter (1993) notes that, in theory, public/private partnerships make promises about greater efficiency, reduced costs, and greater services (p. 18).

Following the line of thought originated by Lowi (1979) The definition posited for this work embraces components of these and many other definitions while stressing the inherent social and political aspects of partnerships.

Intrinsically, this works argues that successful partnerships are adaptive organizations that are unique to their own situation and circumstances. This distinctiveness, however, does not mean there are not shared, or common, qualities of successful partnerships. Borrowing from recent work in the Community Out-Reach Partnership Center (COPC) evaluation field, this work argues that successful partnerships will (1) build the capacity of the stakeholders to change their environment, (2) allow the stakeholders to learn from one another and give them the ability to do things they could not do before, and (3) increase the social, intellectual, and political capital of the partnership (Rubin and Rubin, 1992, p. 16).

As demonstrated, the term partnership is used to describe any numerous situations involving a relationship between two or more parties working toward a common goal. Within this work, however, the term partnership means much more, even without a definitive definition.

Based on the personal interviews and the literature on partnerships it becomes obvious that real partnerships are about trust and the sharing of resources and power. Looking back to the metaphor of partnerships as communities, a definition of successful partnerships must include 1) stakeholders from many different economic sectors, 2) all of whom share a common vision of the future and, 3) are committed to continued experimentation, 4) in achieving mutually agreed upon goals. Furthermore, by being committed, the stakeholders agree to 5) look past their own narrow interests by compromising and showing an appreciation of each others strengths, and an understanding and acceptance of each others weaknesses.. • Approach their dealings with education with a sense of 'controlled impatience'.
• Not believe there is a 'silver bullet' or owner's manual to bring about educational improvement. • Be sensitive to the challenges and limitations schools face.

• Be convinced that the enthusiasm of teachers and students is the indispensable element in good schools. • Come to understand the difficult and time-consuming nature of school system changes and the need to support and stick with a few good ideas for a long time. • Appreciate the history and current reality of imperfect school-business relationships and their share of the responsibility:
The sometimes uneven and unreliable character of business involvement and commitment The inveterate short-term perspective on change and results

The inevitability mixed motives in policy trade-offs between support for adequate education spending and reluctance to embrace new taxes • Show up (which is 90 percent of success in life, as Woody Allen says) knowing that recurrent meetings and rituals are just as important as dramatic announcements and exciting political victories.

The overarching emphasis to be gleaned from Timpane (1991) is that during this stage of the game, continued involvement ---continued partnering ---is the important objective. It took two decades for business to come back into the educational arena, and it will probably take that long for significant changes to show up in measurable outcomes. This research is about the political reality of Public/Private Partnerships in Education. Currently, what makes a partnership successful is the continued participation on the part of business and industry in public education.

As complex organizations, partnerships are dynamic in adapting to their ever-changing environments and stable in their dedication and commitment to their vision and goals. To measure such a dynamic organization "requires clever balance between hard numbers and narrative accounts that can put a story behind that string of numbers (Rubin and Rubin, 1992, p.
12)." The researcher must acknowledge the varying organizational practices and the scope and diversity of partnerships while cognitively and thematically categorizing commonalties. No small task.
However difficult, this research style is required for this investigation. Trachman (1994) summarizes the current feelings about the evaluation of Public/Private Partnerships in Education.

The research literature…is now huge…with informative 'how-to' books illustrating specific practices and policies that support success….While this focus is critical at the beginning, the development of relevant outcome measures is key to continuation and replication. Clearly, improving and expanding these interactions through rigorous evaluation procedures is the next step (Trachman, 1994, p. 2).

However well intentioned Trachtman may be, there are two significant points of contention to be found in the above testimony. First, best practices are not only important to partnering during formulation, but throughout the entire lifecycle of a partnership.

Experimentation and learning are continuous objectives. This, of course, assumes that a partnership will survive the early stages of its lifecycle. If so, best practices are invaluable tools to communicate to other partnerships striving to increase their chances of survival.

Second, the statement assumes that outcomes and, more importantly, outcome measures are isophomorphic and applicable across partnerships. The logic implies that successful partnerships, as identified by outcomes, can be continued and replicated. But the sad truth is that an output measure tells an evaluator nothing about how to continue the actions that led to the outcome, let alone how to replicate those actions across different venues and cultures.
Thus, this work attempts to identify common themes across partnerships that address continued political viability. This discussion now turns to the first of several of these important themes.

div.head: Partnerships and Power
div.p: One component of political models, irrespective of their subject matter, that often proves problematic is power. This work is not exempt from this difficulty. Hence, power is a component of this model of partnership success that is not explicitly measured, yet is implicitly important as it gives rise to many structural manifestations. Thus, critical to this discussion of social organization is the inherent power and politics of collective behavior.

More specifically, this thesis is grounded in the notion of power; how it is manifest; how it is distributed, if at all; and where it comes from. At the very foundation of this work is the assumption that collective behavior requires power, and that it produces power. How this power is fashioned and put to use manifests in the formal model of partnership success hypothesized herewithin. It is through power that partnerships come together and how they stay viable.

This research assumes that the concept of power is oblique, at best, and that power itself is diffuse and nebulous unless focused by some tangible and instrumental means. Czarniawska (1996) relates that "..'power' stands for range of association: actors associate with other actors…and the more numerous and important their associations are, the greater is the power of the whole network thus created (p. 7)."

In terms of Public/Private Partnerships in Education, the implicit overarching goal is power. If the educational system lacks power then it will never achieve other goals that are outcome based. Goals like students being prepared for work, increased academic achievement, and increased retention and graduation rates all rely on the ability of the system to harness and utilize resources. Alone this task is overwhelming, but by building a power and political base the task becomes less formidable, although still difficult.

As Foucault (1980) What makes power such an appealing topic is that although power is often talked about in the negative, the undeniable fact remains that power is also capable of producing positives. In modern society, the state has developed procedures and techniques "…which allowed the effects of power to circulate in a manner at once continuous, uninterrupted, adapted and 'individualized' throughout the entire social body (Foucault, 1980, p. 119)." For Public/Private Partnerships in Education, the existence of these techniques mean that stakeholders not only can use power to create partnerships, but partnerships can also produce power. The process of creating and harnessing power and the relevance to subsequent relations are undeniably important topics, but ones that are too complex for this work. Power is acknowledged in this work, but dissecting power to the point of reductionism is avoided. Thus, in partnerships, the understanding must be of what generates the power, and how the power can be used. What is not important is any discussion of domination on the part of one stakeholder or another. Although these statements may be read as contradictory, they are not. It is a matter of level and of degree, in an applied sense. One cannot blindly deny power, for that would negate the notion of the creation and utilization of partnership power. But, neither can one myopically dissect power, worrying about the true power base. The argument herewithin is that although power can be created by partnerships, it remains diffuse and oblique -in its application.

What makes the generation of power so important to Public/Private Partnerships in Education is that power is a tool that can be used in overcoming the limitations of ambiguity in society, and the complex problems that education began facing in the 1980s. Here again is the dual nature of power. On the one hand, it is a way to overcome these problems, but power also flows out of the very process of handling these problems. Power is one of the few resources that is not limited, and may be self perpetuating.

Taking a lead from the literature on community organizing and revitalization, several actions can be proposed that will aid partnerships in gaining power. First, partnerships can try to take control of the public agenda. By becoming politically viable and including stakeholders from all sectors of the community while facilitating shared meaning, partnerships can work to help the broader community decide which issues should be defined as formal public problems and placed on the systemic agenda (Pressman and Wildavsky, 1984;Starling, 1988). Second, partnerships, as publics, can work toward increasing the level of "consciousness" about issues and problems (Lipsky, 1980). Thus, the partnership can communicate that their goals are really the goals of the broader community; not just narrow problems addressed out of self-interest.

Partnerships can also use legal action to advance their position and/or goals. Although court action can be costly and time consuming, it can bring about desired change and also help to bring attention to the partnership. In a similar fashion, stakeholders can stage protests and demonstrations to create awareness about their cause. Last, and the guiding principle of this work, is the fact that in the public arena the main source of power is the cultivation of people.
People have skills, expertise, resources, and the potential to influence government through voting (Rubin and Rubin, 1992, p. 7).

For power to be harnessed, and for the organization to grow and thrive, this model of success argues that leadership and leadership advocacy are necessary. Hence a brief review of the leadership literature is called for.

div.head: Leadership/Advocacy
div.p: As partnership leaders strive to advance the vision of their organization they must acknowledge that there is an inherent reciprocal relationship between the structure of a partnership and its leadership. Just as strong bodies channel energy into strength to accomplish physical tasks, strong leaders/advocates channel power into their partnerships. In both cases, the avenue of power, i.e., the body or the leader, also can become further energized by the completion of the task.

If power is shared equally in a partnership it may be viewed as having a lateral or flat organizational structure. Current literature on the interdependencies of organizational membership in high-technology industries shows that equality of power is an important characteristic of these organizations (Cleveland, 1985). If partnerships are similar and have high levels of interdependencies, there are several basic roles that leaders fulfill. Summarizing the vast amount of knowledge about leadership, available in works like the Handbook of Leadership (Bass, 1981), this work posits that there are four important roles for partnership leaders. First, leadership must see that the goals are clear and that there is a strategy in place to achieve those goals. Second, leadership must help the stakeholders, and the entire partnership, build its capacity to implement a goal achieving strategy. The third role for leadership in a lateral organization is to create teams of stakeholders or employees to implement the day-to-day project tasks. The final role of leadership is to 'manage' the entire process while ensuring accountability.
Public/private partnerships bring stakeholders from varied backgrounds to the same table in an effort to realize the accomplishment of goals that, individually, could not be achieved.

These goals may be process oriented, or outcome based (Otterbourg, 1990). Along with their respective backgrounds, stakeholders may also bring individual agendas that drive their personal and/or professional participation in the partnership. Because of these factors "Each additional person has many potential effects: he or she may add relevant perceptions and insights, may be perceived as a source of support, may increase the feelings of risk of…principles if not trusted or if he or she has power over [other participants] (Walton, 1987, p. 103)."

Where such situations exist, it is of vital importance for the advocate to act as moderator/mediator. A strong leader is much like an objective third party that negotiates and manages conflict. Borrowing from the conflict literature, the argument made here is that the three greatest assets an advocate can have are power, knowledge, and neutrality (Walton, 1987, 1. Goals for the school district that a sizeable majority can support….and the education of the children should be the overriding concern.
2. An open procedure for setting goals. It requires a school board that is not afraid of controversy, and the participation of teachers, students, and the business community.

div.head: Decentralization in decision making. [Local control of schools] promotes unity
div.p: and growth at each school and allows the superintendent and central office more time for other, larger (though not necessarily more important) problems. 4. Standard operating procedures that are known to be fair and known to be followed (Estes, 1974, p 29-30).

To summarize, "One of the major tasks of the institutional leader is to weld the members of the organization into a 'committed polity,' with a high sense of identity, purpose, and commitment (Perrow, 1986, p. 167)."
Along with leadership and leadership advocacy, another theorized component of successful partnering is the strong support of the media and the broader community.

div.head: Media/Popular Support As Molotch (1979) writes
div.p: A social movement must create a societal context in which it can survive, prosper, and ultimately, triumph. One important resource in providing for this fertile context is the mass media and, in particular, the print and broadcast news (p. 153).

In the late 1970s, a trend in mass media started when business and industry began strongest advocates for the policies and programs of their partnership. What actions they take and how they promote their partnership varies tremendously, but this work argues that the most successful ones have the support of their publics and the media.

The first way in which the media create a positive context for partnerships is through informing the public about the critical issues that the partnership addresses. "Most issues have potential indicators of their objective severity or risk as a social problem. Often the indicator is a single variable (Dearing, 1996, p. 28)" but at other times there may be multiple economic and social indicators that influence public perceptions -and their actions. High teenage pregnancy rates, high drop out rates from school, declining achievement scores, and the stable, if not increasing, levels of teen drug addiction all send clear messages the public at large. Of course how this type of data is packaged is extremely important. The general public does not always react to the objective components, and it sometimes takes 'imagery' to gain the public's attention.

In addition to drawing attention to issues, Dearing (1996) argues that "The mass media often have a direct influence on the policy agenda-setting process, in addition to their indirect influence through the public agenda-setting process (p. 74)." This work on partnerships posits that by setting the public agenda the media helps in creating environments that are friendly to Public/Private Partnerships in Education. In addition to the hard work of partnership leaders and stakeholders in building support, the media play an important role in this effort.
The term 'media' is defined as television and newspaper, since these two formats are the most influential in agenda setting and in building popular support through continued exposure.

In addition, it must be stated that television and newspaper are equally important, and that a partnership that secures the support of only one format may not be as successful. Comstock relates that …in conjunction with other mass media [television] probably has some influence on the public's agenda of who and what is important, although the evidence …is somewhat stronger for newspapers… (Comstock, 1979, p. 193).

However, it is also clear that two mediums play different, but similar roles in society. 'Their influence is at work at different times, operating in different styles, and with different technologies (Eyal, 1986, p. 171)," but both newspapers and television play important roles in agenda setting. It is also true that exposure to one type of media can increase the exposure to another type. According to Witt "…hearing a news story on television or radio actually increases the likelihood that a person will read about that event in a newspaper (Witt, 1983, p.

The popular 'model' of today's media is one in which they appear to respond to the public's right to know by reporting events while acting freely from any outside influence (Altschull, 1984, p. 114). However, as Altschull (1984) argues, this 'model' is more mythical than not, and there is an ideology driving the media. This ideology is economic based, market oriented, and privileges the distribution of goods in its content. He writes, "In modern mass society, the news media more than any other institution facilitate the distribution of goods (Altschull, 1984, p. 123)."

Although his comment may be contested, it does seem fairly clear that current society is market oriented. This orientation has even grown so persuasive that public stakeholders in educational partnerships often refer to their students as their 'product.' Irrespective of philosophical, moral, and meta-ethical debates on this subject, the action is a pragmatic one that aligns schools and school stakeholders on the side of the student. The reality of public education in the early part of this century is that students need to be better prepared for the workforce.

Thus, it is not only plausible, but highly probable that Public/Private Partnerships in Education will find very supportive, and powerful, allies in the media. However, the media also are 'entertainment' oriented and often avoid 'preaching' by focusing on individual issues rather than on broader themes. Altschull (1995) describes the situation by quoting Herbert Gans "...'the news supports the social order of public, business and professional, upper-middle-class, middleaged, and white male sectors of society'.... [and] journalists in the United States emphasize people over groups and 'enduring social values' (Altschull, 1995, p. 129)." Nice reports about successful partnership programs that lead to increased profitability for local businesses, or a series on local kids who 'overcame diversity' by going through a partnership's program are the types of stories the media dream about. As already discussed, however, helping build a good public image is only one way in which the media can support partnerships.

As Dye and Zeigler (1989) state: "The most important power of the mass media is agenda setting….The media creates some issues and obscures others (p. 117)." It is through this power that Public/Private Partnerships in Education can work to promote their issues, their goals, and, ultimately, their public agenda. Gandy (1982) goes even further by suggesting a media model of "information subsidies" that reduce levels of uncertainty in decision making. The implication for partnerships is that "[information] is valued for its ability to...influence individual and collective behaviors through the selective reduction of uncertainty (Gandy, 1982, p. 197)." This level of reduced uncertainty can mean not only greater participation on the part of all stakeholders in a partnership, but greater levels of political viability and, hence, success.

There are several ways in which the media may be enticed to support the activities of partnerships. First, as Estes (1974), argues, an advocate "…should establish an 'official' or regular relationship with groups that have power, visibility, and organization (p. 30)." By utilizing such a relationship, the partnership acts to become visible to the media. Second, a broad base of stakeholders will attract the attention of the media. Very rarely do divergent groups come together for common causes. When they do, the media should be informed. Third, by promoting their programs and interventions attention may be brought to their cause and their partnership. Open houses and staged media events raise the awareness level of the entire community, including the media.

Once the media begin to report on the actions of the partnership, the level of general public interest should increase. Astute partnerships will monopolize on this increasing level by taking action to solidify their position. This solidification may be accomplished in three ways.

First, when the level of popularity hits a critical mass, opponents and detractors to the partnerships may be asked to participate in the partnership by becoming stakeholders. This has the dual effect of increasing the power base of the partnership and brining in fresh ideas.

Second, the partnership can "showcase" their current accomplishments. By hosting "open houses" or tours of facilities, the abstract partnership becomes more concrete to the broader community. Last, partnerships can work at refining, or even redefining, their goals by encouraging the newly discovered public to participate in the partnership. Thus, although it is best to have varied stakeholders in the beginning, often partnerships will not have the necessary high level of exposure to attract a broad base. As the public's interest level increases, the partnership should resist the temptation to keep "our partnership" isolated from those who have become interested.

Once a partnership moves from the informal to the formal stage of organization, the roles and characteristics of the stakeholders often change (Mintzberg, 1979). For that matter, there may be a complete changeover in stakeholders as the organization redefines itself. It is at this point that some partnerships fail without some sort of counter weight.

div.head: Stability/Implementation
div.p: When a partnership begins to stabilize, it, in a sense, begins the process of institutionalization. As partnerships grow and expand, their levels of complexity naturally grow also. This growth often translates into a more rigid structure as informal interactions are replaced by formalized relationships. This formalization of structure and procedures has a dual effect on the partnership. First, and as intended, it creates a sense of stability that is necessary for the effective implementation of the agreed upon strategy. However, it may also bring with it the unintended consequence of a stifling organizational rigidity. Successful partnerships embrace the former while avoiding the latter. How they accomplish this feat is directly related to the structuring variables of vision, goals, and means, and the process variable of leadership.

Summarizing Mintzberg (1979), the evolution from informal to formal organization occurs when more frequent and higher-priority coordination is needed. Formal teams or workgroups are created to manage frequently occurring tasks and to reduce the number and severity of the uncertainties associated with greater complexity. Effective leaders balance the need for greater structure, in handling uncertainty, with the desire for creativity and informality in task completion. It takes a skillful hand to bring balance on such a delicate fulcrum.
In his discussion of organizational decision-making, Downs (1994) identifies several

threats to a growing organization as it transitions from the informal to the formal. First, and as important as obvious, there are multiple decision-makers (p. 178). This one simple change can cause more damage to an organization than any other. Although, by definition, partnerships are collective behavior, they often start small with one person serving as the catalyst to the majority of action. As the partnership grows, more people become involved and the various stakeholders voice different, and sometimes conflicting, visions, goals, and action plans, resulting in an ever increasingly complicated process.

Hand-in-hand with multiple decision-makers is the influx of worldviews that come into a partnership. Often times, two people can see the exact same event and have completely different interpretations. Magnify this disjointed nexus by a large number of stakeholders and you can see the potential for heated discussion. An added dimension to throw in is the makeup of most stakeholders involved in partnerships. Coming from various economic sectors and different educational and cultural backgrounds amplifies the noise even more. A strong personality with good mediation skills often eases the pressure that comes from committee decision making and mixed interpretations. A skilled mediator shows the decision making body the strengths of multiple interpretations, rather than focusing on the conflict, divergence, perceived weaknesses and other distractions.

Multiple communication channels and the associated errors are two other threats borrowed from Downs (1994, p. 178). Although these type of threats are exceedingly difficult to manage, a stabilizing agent can reduce any extraneous and/or unnecessary communications by keeping stakeholders informed of 'real' issues and limiting the amount of rumors and hearsay that clog communication lines.
Looking at the literature on policy-making, Stone (1988) posits that a changing agenda requires a change in membership. This postulate is assumed to be just as true for partnerships.

Thus, as the partnership moves from informal to formal and grows in scope, the actions that the partnership takes will also begin to change. At this point it may become impossible for the initial makeup of stakeholders to contend with the changing internal and external environments. A stabilization agent can recognize this phenomena and bring calm to the partnership by facilitating a change in stakeholders. As Stone (1988) relates "the qualities and interests of people who make decisions shape the kinds of decisions they make (p. 291)." This change in decisionmakers is an on-going process and requires that a stabilization agent always be present in the partnership, if it is to survive (the changes).

Of course, the stabilization agent is not always going to be the same either. As an organization flows through its life cycle all forms of stakeholders and partnership components will ebb and flow. What gives the partnership an advantage in success and survival is the level to which it can adapt to all of the internal and external uncertainties. The discussion now turns to learning organizations and their ability to adapt.

div.head: Means To Goals
div.p: Following in the line of thought detailed by Senge (1990), this work argues that organizations that are "learning" organizations, as opposed to "knowing" organizations are more flexible in their decision making processes, and, therefore, more likely to succeed while facing uncertainty and diverse environments.

One facet of a learning organization is the ability to be flexible and fluid in selecting strategies to achieve partnership goals. Partnerships that prefer to minimize risk by using tried and true means miss the opportunity to bring about desired change. The successful organization will experiment as it searches for the most effective way to achieve its goals. But, it is not just the experimentation that is important, it is the generation of knowledge ---the learning from mistakes ---that marks a successful organization. As Nonaka (1991) The most effective citizen groups are board-based…whose interests are not restricted to educational issues. Such groups appeal to a wider variety of people and have more opportunities for support (p. 84).

Such support enhances the power focusing ability of partnerships and even generates additional power. By building a community built on shared reality, "They can also share political clout through alliances on issues of common concern (NSPRA, 1977, p. 85)."

This model of success makes a very explicit assumption about the type of organization that results in the continued existence of the partnership. The key organizational characteristic of success is the ability of the organization to learn. In addition, if successful partnerships are best viewed as learning organizations, then the means used to achieve goals must also be part of the learning process, a function not typically associated with rigid bureaucracy. The type of organizational structure best suited to facilitate this process is a structure that not only is flexible in how it approaches implementation, but takes the initiative to create knowledge as it works towards its goals. Chapter three will continue this discussion of organization instrumentality in greater detail as the formal model of partnership success is outlined.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: This chapter has laid the foundation for the formal model of partnership success that follows. Several critical assumptions and partnership components were outlined and discussed.

The chapter started by looking at the amorphous concept of power and how it applies to Public/Private Partnerships in Education. As an extension of power, the discussion turned to leadership and leadership advocacy and how both of these partnership components can work to increase a partnership's power base.

Next, the role and importance of the media in gaining popular support for partnerships was addressed. An acknowledgement of the dynamic nature of partnering and how stability can be induced into the process followed that section. This chapter then concluded with a brief argument in support of partnerships as an instrumentality to achieve goals.

In chapter three this discussion of partnerships as organizations is continued by examining the organizational structures and their relationship with ideology and vision. The chapter sets the stage for chapters five and six in which the univariate and multivariate data analyses are presented for consideration.

div.head: Chapter Three: Partnership Formation ============ PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS IN EDUCATION ============
div.p: Continuing the review started in the previous chapter, this discussion examines the theoretical foundation of successful partnerships in education, with the presentation in this chapter divided into two sections. Although the abstract concepts of partnerships, success, and power detailed in chapter one are of the utmost importance to this research, relevant too is the more concrete concept of partnerships as organizations. In the first half, the key chapter concepts are presented and defined while building the context for a formal model of partnership success. In order of presentation, these concepts are public/private partnership as organization, the importance of clear goals to partnership success, and, finally, the role of ideology and the process of visioning in structuring partnerships.

The second section of this chapter addresses the corollary processes by which goals, means, and vision are brought to fruition through the organizational process. This section and the chapter will culminate with a general model of partnership success and its description.

div.head: Partnerships As Organization
div.p: Chapter two included a discussion of power and how it is inherent in all forms of social organization. That discussion also included the importance of focusing power to accomplish goals. And, one obvious social mechanism that exists to focus power is that of human organization with a fundamental assumption of this work being that partnerships, like any collective behavior, are best understood as organizations. The puzzle, of course, then becomes detailing what type of organization they are and how they are best understood. The first section of this chapter addresses these questions by continuing the identification of components across successful partnerships, turning attention from process to structure.

To accomplish this task, it is necessary to look to the literature from organizational theory. It is also important to stress that none of the organizational components of this model exist in isolation. Hence, all components are theoretically interrelated and work as an emergent system.

A traditional, and often loathed, approach for achieving shared societal goals has been to develop a bureaucracy. This type of organization has as its defining characteristic a rigid hierarchical structure that has been well noted over the years, most notably by Weber (1946).

The role and relevance of bureaucracy in the policy process has also been well document (Kingdon, 1984;Nakamura and Smallwood, 1980;Starling, 1988). As policy and programs have been formulated through one process, the implementation has been carried out through another -most often the process of bureaucratization.

In the pursuit of their common goals, partnerships too rely on an organizational Starting in the early part of the last century with the rise of scientific management, the study of human organization and organizational theory began to take on a greater aura of functional legitimacy. Nonetheless, those early theories, and even the most recent theories, i. e., those that focus on organizations as culture (Martin, 1992;Schein, 1992;Siehl, 1985) tend to examine intra-organization relationships, with respect to identifying causal mechanisms, that prove useful in improving the efficiency of the organization. Even "systems" theory (Thompson, 1967), which concentrates on the impact of environmental forces on organizations, only addresses the adaptive capabilities of modern organization. The issues of using organizations as a technology, and the consequences of such a use are not addressed in an explicit fashion. Also, when discussions of modern organization do turn from intraperspective dialogues to broader issues, the emphasis is placed on the impacts that organizations have on individuals (Denhardt, 1981) or on culture (Morgan, 1986). Again, although these issues are of great concern to organizational and administration theorists, the missing element is the fashion in which organizations are conceptualized in their design and application. The implications of such a design and application paradigm of organizational technology are not explicitly portrayed in the literature.

Irrespective of this lack of attention, many theorists and practitioners implicitly treat organizations as technologies. The metaphor of organization as technology is a powerful one. It captures the raw essence of collective instrumentality to achieve goals. However, it is important to acknowledge that to fully understand a phenomenon it is necessary to go beyond the building of a meta-text and to move into the realm of applied practice. That is, the effort here is to go beyond metaphor building to describe the relationship between partnership structure and its value base. Thus, the goal is to suggest a postulate or two about how the two components interact in the practice of Public/Private Partnerships in Education.

Martin (1992), as a postmodern organizational theorist, argues that contemporary organizations exist in complex and dynamic environments and that they face high levels of ambiguity. This ambiguity results in organizations that lack clear centers and "interactions among members are often fleeting and superficial (p. 131)." Further, one approach used to understand the impact of ambiguity on organizations is to rely on differentiation theory and the study of subgroups within the organization. Martin (1992) makes a strong case against such theory by arguing that focusing on the dichotomies in organizations means the researcher "…oversimplifies and misrepresents the attributes and viewpoints of members…(p. 135)." This is the case with Public/Private Partnerships in Education. To dichotomize stakeholders into two or more groups has a very negative effect. Hence, it minimizes the important similarities that stakeholders from the two sectors bring to the table, and second, it increases the negative energy that can manifest from focusing on differences rather than similarities. Clearly, stakeholders from different sectors have different perspectives and may interpret their worlds differently, to a degree, but they have much in common, also.

In the current era of fiscal devolution, private and public stakeholders bring many more commonalties to the partnership table than they do differences. Many stakeholders from both sectors attended the same universities, have children in the same school district, socialize in the same circles, and attend religious services together. To focus on differences and create animosity between groups not only minimizes the shared reality of their participation in the partnership, but also lays the foundation for the destruction of partnership power. On the other hand, by stressing the commonalties, rather than differences, otherwise negative energy is turned into focused power.

What stakeholders must do, if the partnership is to be successful, is to learn from one another and about one another. They must build on their strengths, and compensate for one another's weaknesses. A successful partnership is not a "knowing" organization, it is a learning organization (Senge, 1990; Georgivesky, 1997).

Part of organizational learning also involves the stakeholders developing the ability to group process a clear mission and agreement on partnership goals. Without this critical ability the partnership may never get on solid enough ground to have a shot at survival. The importance of a clear mission is now discussed in detail. Goals, on the other hand, are more specific statements about how that vision will be realized.

div.head: The Importance Of Clear Mission/Goals
div.p: Irrespective of this difference, it is of utmost importance for partnerships to clarify both mission and goals early on in their lifecycle.
The complex and definition defying nature of partnering has led at least one observer to state:

The concept of urban partnerships has come to imply a sustained collaborative effort of two or more institutions -one public, the other private -in which each of the participants shares in the planning of projects and programs designed to meet a collective need and contributes resources. Since partnership definitions are neither conceptually neat nor empirically rigorous, one is left with certain basic characteristics that run throughout most successful ventures. These include equality among participants, shared risk, and perceived mutual benefits (Haider, 1986, p. 139).

In order to share the risk and benefit from collective action it is imperative for partnerships to have clear and mutual goals. Clear mission and goal statements serve three functions in contributing to partnership viability. First, they serve as a communication conduit to the broader community. As will be discussed later, a mission statement transmits the values and ideology of a partnership into the community. Second, a clear set of goals helps the stakeholders to focus and build internal buy-in. Last, and a value often overlooked, clear goals force an institution to move beyond rhetoric and into the realm of application and functionality. This is not at odds with the first two function, although it may appear this way, at first. The role of ideology and internal partnership culture cannot be undervalued. There are fundamentally two steps in developing clear goals that are of concern to this work. For ease of consideration we will call the first step defining the problem and the second step stating the goals. Within each of these broad categories are sub-steps. The first step in developing clear goals is to identify the specific need(s) to be satisfied and indicate the respective magnitude. To accomplish this task the causes of, or major contributions to, the problem must be isolated. Next, the partnership must identify how specific groups are affected.

In the second step, clear goals must be stated. In this process, the major goals are identified and how these goals relate to the problem is documented. Alternative ways to achieve these goals are then developed and evaluated. This evaluation of the alternatives is based on their relative costs and benefits (it is necessary to broadly define both costs and benefits in order to effectively evaluate) to not only the partnership, but also the broader community. Finally, the impacts of each alternative (both intended and unintended) must be considered prior to selection and implementation.. Ideology can also be used to create a partnership culture among its own stakeholders.

Although there may be a consensus among stakeholders that a problem exists, there may also be numerous perspectives of what the problem is and how best to address it. Downs (1994) refers to this difference in perspective as informational isolation and attributes its existence to "specialization." An ideology facilitates the shared meaning that all stakeholders must have in order to see the overall picture.

As partnerships move through their lifecycles and address different types of problems, their memberships often change with stakeholders entering and leaving. An ideology can help a partnership recruit and attract new stakeholders who may contribute to goal consensus.

Partnerships also face making many decisions on a daily basis. Often these decisions require choosing between two very similar choices. When all other criteria have been used to evaluate the options, ideology can be used to make an otherwise impossible decision. Thus, choices that are consistent with the ideology of the organization are choices that sometimes best serve the organization.

Overall, the development of an organization ideology is an effective means for a Public/Private Partnership in Education to communicate both within and outside its organizational boundaries. Through this increased communication capacity, partnerships are better able to function as a cohesive collective and to achieve their shared organizational goals.

div.head: The Role Of Vision
div.p: The previous sections deal with the importance of goals to a partnership and the ability of partnerships to achieve those goals through an organizational technology. for partnerships to remain open to their internal and external environments. Each of these important aspects of partnership vision will now be addressed.

Thus, the partnership stakeholders must develop and embrace a vision of what they hope to achieve through their collective actions. This vision is often embedded in the mission statement of the partnership and it serves the ideology of the organization best when it is explicit.

There are two complementary aspects of a vision. One aspect is to provide a far-reaching vision of a desired future state. The other is shorter term, and builds a picture of current state of the organization. Where vision parts from pure ideology -in a sense a long-term vision -is in the (short-term) implementation of the vision and the application of mechanisms to bring about the desired condition or changes in the status quo. To be useful, a vision must be practical and describe a situation that is at least plausible, if not reasonable. Although a vision is a lens to the future, it is not a true vision unless it can translate itself into reality. There are 'dreams' and there are visions. According to Nanus, a great leader is a synthesizer who maps the domain of the organization, generates alternative visions, chooses the right vision, packages the vision, and then facilitates the implementation of the vision. Without a strong tie to pragmatic application, vision becomes diluted and the viability of the partnership is weakened.

Conversely, the viability of the partnership also depends on the extent to which the vision, and the subsequent mission and goals, are implemented in terms of alternative actions. A comprehensive vision will not only address the depth of social problems by understanding the systemic nature of such problems, but it will also deny the platitude of symbolic "cures" by searching for the correct fit of solutions and problems. As Kingdon (1984) has so aptly pointed out, often issues only become problems when solutions exist. Partnerships that exercise a high degree of creativity in their definition of issues will be more likely to take advantage of existing solutions.

The successful partnerships will also seek out inventive solutions, where necessary, to the problems they are addressing. Rather than always relying on the tried and true, successful partnerships will experiment with new solutions and exhibit a creative component in their adaptability. As Winter (1990) states …adaptability is not an all-or-nothing proposition, …the pace of adaptation relative to environment change is key, and…differing degrees of adaptability can characterize different activities or characteristics of an organization (Winter, 1990, p. 291).

Thus, there should be sufficient flexibility in achieving a vision. A clear vision and a well thought-out and articulated mission statement serve as important mechanisms in creating equilibrium between partnerships and their environment.

Although many organizations embrace visioning and mission statements, not everyone is convinced of their usefulness. However, if formulated correctly, they can have a simple and direct impact. Falsey (1989) writes For many, it is easy to read a mission statement and be unimpressed. It's easy to say that a mission statement is nothing more than common sense.
It is true that a substantial number of ideas in mission statements are just that. It is equally true, however, that common sense often can be easily overlooked (Falsey, 1989, p. 33).

Thus, it is important for partnerships to maintain a realistic level of expectation and work to ensure that "the partnership's scope (local, regional, state and national) and service areas (rural, suburban and urban) are manageable and controllable (Otterbourg, 1990, p. 5)." Perhaps the greatest asset any partnership can have in mediating this tension between flexible visioning and realistic expectations is strong leadership.

Thus far, this work has centered on the components of partnerships and the instrumentality of partnership organization in achieving shared goals. The discussion now turns to the formation of a model of partnership success that draws upon these aforementioned themes.

div.head: A Theory Of Partnership Success
div.p: In the general model that follows, concepts and ideas are presented that form a foundation for successful partnerships in education. Drawing from the previous chapters and sections on organizational theory, bureaucracy, leadership, and media support, the argument is presented that partnerships that exist in simple environments have the best chance for survival.

In addition, for those that exist in complex environments, it is argued that partnerships will have a greater chance at being successful if the stakeholders are unified in the goals that they develop.
Those partnerships that create and nourish a partnership power through the transformation of personal energy into partnership energy are also theorized to be more successful.

In their work, Burrell and Morgan (1994) describe four theoretical paradigms based on two dimensions. The paradigms are Functional, Interpretive, Humanist, and Structuralist and the two dimensions are change---stability, and subjective---objective. These dimensions give rise to the various structures that are inherent to all organization. It is reasonable to posit that partnerships, as a form of organization, will have similar identifiable structures. These dimensions and the variability in structure are hypothesized to exist across all partnerships.

In addition to the Burrell and Morgan (1994) typology, this work relies heavily on the theories of Senge (1990) in understanding organizations, their structures, and their processes. As the argument is stated:

Structure produces behavior, and changing underlying structures can produce different patterns of behavior. In this sense, structural explanations are inherently generative. Moreover, since structure in human systems includes the 'operating policies' of the decision makers in the system, redesigning our own decision making redesigns the system structure (Senge, 1990, p. 53).

Thus, in line with this argument, this work makes the critical assumption that partnerships have a structure that 'produce behaviors,' but adds to the theory by assuming that this a non-recursive relationship and that behaviors will influence the structure as well. As with all organizations, partnerships are in continuous flux and, thus, always in the process of (re)definition. As Bridges et al. (1997) claim:

Change is not a purely rational process and in order to change practice, the values, attitudes, and beliefs which individuals form as members of professional cultures must be taken into account and addressed (14. 1.3).
What originates from this blending of organizational theories is a model of partnerships as the emergent product of a dialectical process involving structure, values, and environment.

Based on this model, it is further posited that all organizations, i.e., partnerships, have six principle components that interact in three dimensions of partnership space. This model strives to capture the importance of organizational structure, the critical role of policy advocates, and the interaction of structure and process in the emergence of educational partnerships.

The following section gives a rough outline of the general model by giving a brief description of each dimension. This discussion begins by describing the theorized model of partnership structure and by presenting a graphical display of the theorized relationships.

div.head: ORGANIZATINAL STRUCTURE
div.p: Although particular participants and types of interactions will vary across partnerships, all interactions are theorized to occur within a general organizational structure comprised of three dimensions or continua. These dimensions are vague---precise, rigidity---flexibility, and narrow---broad, and constitute three dimensional partnership space.

Within the context of power, organization, ideology, and vision, this model posits that the success of partnerships can be attributed to six conceptual themes. Three of these themes arise from process and mediation, and three emerge from the earliest stages of formation and development and manifest in the form of human capital. These themes influence partnering within the partnership space and are: (1) The ability of a partnership to specify clear and concise goals, (2) The ability of the partnership to adapt to its environment (both internal and external) in working towards meeting its stated goals and objectives, (3) the ability of the partnership to envision its role in a broader system, (4) the presence of a partnership catalyst that brings the partnership together, (5) the presence of broad based community support for the partnership, and

(6) the influx of a stabilization agent that unifies, or "gels" the partnership. Figure 3-1 shows the theorized relationship between a partnership and key components of partnership success, all located within three-dimensional partnership space.

div.head: Figure 3-1
div.p: As is the case with many social models, this particular effort acknowledges that there are many additional unidentified variables that affect partnerships and their degrees of success. The effort here is not to document all possible factors that exist in partnership space, but, rather, document the most relevant and those that apply across venue and context.

The above graphic shows the relationship between a partnership advocate, an agent of stabilization, and support from the media and a partnerships public, all interacting in a organizational structure comprised of three dimensions.

The first dimension, vague---precise, deals with the type of goals set forth by a partnership. It is hypothesized that partnerships that form clear and precise goals will have greater success, in achieving their goals and maintaining a stable organization, than those partnerships that do not. As a structural component, this goals dimension interacts with the other dimensions, as well as the other partnership factors. The above graphic shows the partnership advocate in close proximity to this dimension because there is a theorized strong relationship between goals and leadership, with an advocate as a potential source of this leadership.
However, it must be restated, at this point, that this model assumes that all partnership components interact with the structure and that none exist in isolation.

The second dimension, rigidity---flexibility refers to the ability of the partners to adapt to the emerging nature of the partnership, including its internal and external environments. The belief is that partnerships that can not adapt to change are doomed to failure and the eventual demise of the partnership. As Haider states [All organizations] pass through phases of growth and decline. They are vulnerable to powerful trends and changes in the external environment that, in turn, affect their viability and governance (Haider, 1986, p. 137).

Thus, partnerships face many threats from outside the organization and need to be flexible in adapting to these challenges. This is particularly true in newer organizations that have little support and a diffuse power base. Standard operating procedures and mechanistic reaction to such environmental threats can severely damage a partnership.

As organizations grow, there is a tendency for them to become more rigid in their interaction with outside elements. This work suggests that even for older partnerships, the more successful, even thriving, ones will exhibit a higher degree of flexibility.

The external environment is not the only concern to organizations, however. The With this notion of uncertainty in place, this work argues that partnerships must face their uncertainties with high levels of flexibility as they adapt to their ever changing conditions.
These conditions may be large or small, internal or external, but, which ever is the case, the partnership must not act or react in a rigid fashion.
The last dimension, narrow---broad, refers to the focus or scope of the partnership.

Although this dimension seems at odds with the first, it is not. Partners must delineate clear goals, but, at the same time, they must have a broad vision with respect to how they hope to achieve those goals. Myopia in a partnership will result in mediocre outcomes and disillusioned partners. Gifford argues Like other organizations, a partnership may approach the political process with a systematic political philosophy or with ad hoc responses to individual political situations. Or the partnership may find itself, as is frequently the case, on a point somewhere between these two ends of the spectrum, combining a loose ideology with considerable pragmatism (Gifford, 1986. p. 77).

With potentially high levels of uncertainty, partnerships must keep boundaries fluid and be open to alternative methods to achieve goals. A good balance of ideology and pragmatic experimentation results in partnerships coming up with solutions to unique problems that not only achieve goals, but reinforces partnership power through consensus building. As discussed earlier, organizational ideology is a powerful force and this resource should be tapped while building a partnership vision, and accompanying action plan.

Given this theorized structure, it is now important to detail the formulation and implementation process that is carried out therein. Goodman and Holp (1994b), in their work on ethics legislation, have outlined a model of the policy process that will be used in this dissertation. Applied to the topic at hand, this model hypothesizes that successful partnerships will be formed when three criteria are met.

First, in the planning or partnership agenda setting stage, there will be a strong partnership advocate. In public/private partnerships, this advocate may be an educator, or group of educators, a school board, a parent, a business interest, interest group, or an outside activist such as The Council For Aid To Education. This advocate provides the initial impetus that brings the participants together.

Second, popular support for the partnership must be gained during the formulation process. This is most likely brought about through reports generated in the written and electronic media. This stage is critical to a successful partnership because it prevents entropy from setting in. The influx of energy not only encourages the partners to continue on in their efforts, but acts as a catalyst in attracting new potential partners.

The last component of a successful public/private partnership is a stabilization agent(s) in the implementation stage. Again, the particular agent(s) will vary from case to case, but will exist. This agent(s) serves several important functions. First, the agent(s) ensures that there is effective communication between the participants. The agent(s) works to clarify the goals and objectives of the partnerships and to promote consensus and agreement. Second, the agent(s)

facilitates an effective measure of success. That is, along with clear goals and objectives, the partners must feel that the partnership is meeting some type of objective standard, although this objective is not necessarily defined by outcomes. The agent(s) helps to form, gain consensus on, and implement this standard. Hence, it is important to note that implementing this methodology is not an exercise in grounded theory (Glaser, 1967). That is, the model explicated earlier in this work is the driving theoretical force in the data collection. A series of specific research questions about partnerships were developed and then posited to the partnership stakeholders. Their reactions and comments to these propositions were recorded as field notes and then analyzed for content. This style of simultaneous data collection and analysis allows the shaping and focusing of the study as it proceeds (Glesne, 1999, p. 130).

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: Once the analyses of these qualitative data were complete, the findings were then used to construct a series of process and activity codes (Bogdan, 1998, p. 174) to assist in the structuring of the quantitative mail survey (Appendix B). This self-administered pencil and paper survey was distributed to a sample of partnership stakeholders from across the country. These data then served as the cornerstone of the statistical analysis presented herein.

div.head: QUALITATIVE INTERVIEWS
div.p: This section describes the research protocol followed in collecting the qualitative data via telephone and face-to-face interviews of stakeholders from Flint, Michigan and Cincinnati, Ohio.

The following format is followed in presenting this methodology. First, a brief description of each case study city is presented. Next, the research design is discussed, and then this section ends with a description of the data collection methodology, including instrument design and telephone and in-person interview protocols.

div.head: Participant Selection
div.p: These two case studies provide support to the qualitative component of this dissertation by providing the context of the work and by shaping the design of the mail instrument. The case study cities selected are Flint, Michigan, and Cincinnati, Ohio. These cities were chosen based on the following four criteria. One (1), in order to generate an effective knowledge base about partnerships, information about the partnering stages, i.e., formulation, and implementation, must be collected. These two cases represent different stages in this process. Two (2), the term "partnership" has different meanings in different contexts. These cities represent a dichotomy of stakeholder involvement and provide a contextual understanding of partnering activities based on the degree of participation. Three (3), the partnerships must at least attempt to address systemic problems. Although numerous educational partnerships are concerned with very narrow issues, such as math or science, partnerships with a broader mission will inherently, by definition, represent broader educational issues.

The educational partnership in Flint reflects a diversity of public/private partners and is fairly advanced in terms of its development. Formed in 1990, the Teaming For Excellence partnership brought together 21 Genessee County school districts, business organizations, social service agencies, and four institutions of higher learning in the effort to create new approaches to elementary and secondary schooling. The objectives and goals of the partnership were broad based and focused on the involvement of all partners as an important resource. The stated goals and objectives of the partnership were:

* To establish the Flint Roundtable, comprised of CEOs, to marshall the community's resources. * To implement a comprehensive school improvement strategy. * To increase the community's ability to respond to the changing needs of students and the local economy. * To coordinate support services for youth and their parents, and to improve the transition between education and the work place (Flint Round Table ).
As a broad based attempt at systemic change, the Flint Teaming For Excellence partnership provided valuable insight in the public/private partnership process.

While Flint had an existing broad based partnerships, Cincinnati had yet to form a legitimized partnership at the time these interviews were conducted. Although recent events had occurred within the school district, Cincinnati had not yet matured to a level appropriate for the fruition of an on-going partnership development.

In September of 1991, the Buenger Commission released its study of the Cincinnati public schools calling for revised fiscal policy-making and administrative restructuring (Buenger, 1991). The commission, comprised of Cincinnati business executives, had high expectations of reforming the Cincinnati school district. In the years that have followed, however, it has become clear that the recommendations made in the commission's report have largely went unfulfilled. It is reasonable to expect that had the business community legitimized their relationship with the school board, rather than merely forming recommendations, the level of improvement would have been greater. The institutionalization of the relationship would be one way to bring about legitimization to this Public/Private Partnership in Education.

It is important to note that during these interviews, the school board members appeared more amiable to legitimized partnerships. Indeed, in 1994, members of the school board opened negotiations with the Edison group, a for profit organization that contracts with school boards to manage specific schools. Although this effort did not materialize into a contract, it appears that school board members were willing to experiment in their attempts to improve Cincinnati schools.

As a pre-institutionalized partnership case study, interviews with school board members and business leaders were conducted to identify what factors encourage public/private partnership and to facilitate the measuring of these factors via a mail survey.

div.head: Instrument Development
div.p: The survey instrument was developed over a three-month period of time in the winter of 1995-96. The final instrument was a product of a lengthy process of development and refinement. Along with the literature review, consultation with committee members and other advisors resulted in an instrument designed to provide structure to the interview while allowing flexibility in the range of responses.

The instrument was entirely open-ended and contained twenty questions. The questions concerned the partnering process, how the stakeholders became involved in their partnership, obstacles that the partnership faced, and perceptions of partnership strength and weaknesses.

The instrument changed slightly after interviews with the first two Flint, Michigan stakeholders. During these interviews, it became apparent that two follow-up questions to the question "How would you define the relationship between the public and private sector?" were not only redundant, but could be taken as leading questions. In order to preserve objectivity and eliminate even a chance of perceived bias, these questions were removed.

div.head: Data Collection
div.p: These data were collected over a six-week period in January and February of 1996.

Using an instrument containing twenty questions, the majority of interviews were conducted by telephone. Given the busy schedules of all the participants, some interviews were completed by placing telephone calls to the stakeholder's home. In all, there were twenty-one-attempted interviews with Cincinnati stakeholders and nineteen completes. Due to the close geographical proximity of the city of Cincinnati, this researcher traveled there to conduct two of the interviews and even met one participant at the University of Dayton Alumni Hall to complete an interview.
There were twenty-one-completed interviews with Flint stakeholders, and all of these were completed by telephone.

Flint was selected for inclusion because of its outstanding reputation in the educational partnership literature. This reputation was primarily due to the high level of participation and commitment of the Flint Roundtable, a business panel comprised of numerous business activists.
The process of identifying and contacting Flint stakeholders started with the Roundtable.

After several telephone calls to the Roundtable, a high ranking official agreed to participate in the interview process and provided the names and telephone numbers of other major stakeholders. A snowball approach was implemented as each subsequent participant was asked to name other likely stakeholders for inclusion. Interestingly, most of the stakeholders named potential participants from numerous sectors of the economy. That is, in contrast to the expectation, business stakeholders were as likely to recommend stakeholders from education or government as they were to suggest another business participant. In addition, the final list of twenty-one participant stakeholders is very close to the list of names that were continually mentioned by all stakeholders. Thus, the Flint stakeholders were a fairly close knit group and seemed to have overcome (in)significant differences in order to achieve their shared goal.

In contrast, the Cincinnati stakeholders mentioned many names and the list of participants had to be limited. There were many individuals recommended for inclusion based on their unique perspective, but who were not as active in the partnering process. As with Flint, the process of selection followed a snowball methodology and started with the Cincinnati Downtown Partnership organization.

Again, as in Flint, several telephone calls to this organization were rewarded by the agreement of a high ranking official to participate in the interview process. Several other business stakeholders were recommended because of their involvement in the "Buenger Report (1991)," a document intended to improve the quality of the Cincinnati Public School System (CPS).

These business stakeholders were quick to participate and provided the names and telephone numbers of other community members who also participated in the Buenger Report process. Although there were high levels of participation among the stakeholders from the various economic sectors, Cincinnati differed from Flint in the level of agreement and singularity of vision that existed. With the Cincinnati stakeholders, not only was there a diversity of views between groups, i.e., educators, business, or not-for-profit, but also within the groups.
Consensus was not a defining characteristic of the partnership.
