Once the data were collected, they were subjected to statistical analysis in a hybrid exploratory/confirmatory process attempting to flesh out the rudimentary hypotheses formed during the literature review. For the statistical test component, path analyses were employed.

In a structural equation path analysis, Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) linear regression paths are used to test the strength of (1) individual linear paths of influence by independent variables on dependent variables, and (2) a general linear model of causation. If the model outlined is correctly specified, path analyses allow general statements to be made about the causal mechanisms at work, in this case the components that contribute to successful educational public/private partnerships.

For this work, a combination of structural (organizational) and policy (process) variables are used to predict the success of partnerships, i.e., the dependent variable. Based on the two components, i.e., structure and process, of the general theory outlined in the previous chapters, the following model is constructed. The dependent variable is the success, or failure, of a partnership, as defined by a scale constructed from survey questions. The construction of this variable was based on the results of the initial telephone and face-to-face interviews.

The decision to let the partners self-define success is founded in the lack of theoretical work in the area of educational partnerships. Although there has been empirical work done in the study of partnerships in various disciplines like Local Economic Development (LED), this literature does not yield any substantive measure of success that is applicable to educational partnerships. Thus, the partners themselves are viewed as the experts in their field of educational partnerships. It was this expertise that was tapped in developing a valid measure of success.

Several general statements must be made about this measure. First, as with most complex concepts, this dependent variable is multidimensional in nature and, thus, difficult to operationalize with one, singular measure. The expectation, from the very beginning, was that the question of what constitutes a successful partnership would elicit a wide range of responses during qualitative data collection. This expectation was confirmed and, thus, the reliance on a scale measure that is more robust than any single measure of partnership success.

Second, the political dimensions of success are assumed to be the ultimate theoretical concepts and are used in the construction of the scale measure. These singular measures include the likelihood of participation in a different partnership, the likelihood of continued participation in the current partnership, the level of stakeholder satisfaction with partnership success, and a stakeholder rating of partnership success -all of which are acknowledged self-reports.

It must also be noted that although there was strong agreement on the part of stakeholders concerning goal attainment as one measure of success, this measure was included in the model as an intervening variable, not as part of the dependent scale measure. For many stakeholders, if the goals of the partnership have been obtained, then the partnership can be viewed as a success.
However, many partnerships achieve their goals and still fail politically. It is this observation that drives the decision for this measure to be included as an endogenous independent variable.
In short, this model theorizes that success of partnerships, as measured by our multiple political dimensions, is influenced by the actualization of goal obtainment.

div.head: Sampling Procedure
div.p: The sampling frame from which the respondents were drawn was purchased from the National Association of Partnerships in Education (NAPE). This organization is a not-for-profit agency that aids schools in building and fostering educational partnerships by providing resources and expertise in the field.

As stated at their official web page, the association develops leaders with the skills and knowledge to build community consensus around local systemic education reform. Their reform efforts focus on four strategic directions.
• Building collaborative leadership for education reform;
• Strengthening state and local leadership;
• Focusing leadership for change; and
• Measuring and sharing the progress of partnerships in contributing to the success of students (NAPE).

The data set was purchased from NAPE in June of 1996, and included all current members of the association, as of that date. NAPE classifies all members as belonging to one of seven categories, business sector; Chamber of Commerce; education, i.e., public and private primary and secondary schools; higher education; governmental members; non-profit sector; and those classified as something 'other' than any of the above categories. For this last category, the database was so ambiguous as to their relevancy to Public/Private Partnerships in Education that these cases were excluded from the sample.

In total, the sampling frame contained 1,816 records and Table 4-1 shows a breakdown of membership by count and percent. The survey instrument contained a question asking respondents to self classify themselves as belonging to one of six categories. Over four out of ten (41.95%) respondents classified themselves as school administrators, eighty (24.32%) as businesspersons, and eightynine (27.05%) responded they were something other than the options given. The remaining twenty-two cases reported their positions as either school board (0.61%), civic leader (1.52%), or teacher (4.56%). Table 4

div.head: -3 displays this information.
div.p: There is a discrepancy between the assigned classification counts and the self reported classifications. For example, eighty respondents reported being from business, while the number of responses from this same category was tracked at ninety-two. This imprecision is most likely due to the ambiguity of roles in partnering and the way in which NAPE administers its database. Due to limited resources and the desire for an adequate sample size, questionnaires were mailed to the entire population. If resources were more abundant, a random selection of stakeholders would have been selected and multiple mailings implemented. Given the realities, however, only one mailing was carried out and the 340 responses to the survey are deeply appreciated. These cases give great insight into the workings of partnerships and provide an adequate sample size for this investigation. Given the aforementioned budgetary limits of this research, and the single mailing to potential respondents, the total response rate for this survey was a respectable 18.7%. Certainly, if reminder post-cards, or a second copy of the survey had been sent out, this figure could easily have been doubled.

div.head: Instrument Design
div.p: Instrument design was based on the literature and the findings from the telephone and face-to-face qualitative interviews. In addition, advise was sought from committee members and their recommendations played a critical role in improving the instrument. The questions are designed to measure six independent variables and the dependent variable scale measure.. In all, there are forty-six closed-ended questions on the instrument, and two open-ended.

div.head: Treatment Of Data
div.p: Once all surveys were collected, they were pre-coded and the responses entered into the Statistical Program for the Social Sciences (SPSS) over a two-week period in September and October of 1997. When the data entry was finished, random cases were selected for a quality control check. Any discrepancies were corrected and another error check was performed.

Analyses of these data were also conducted using SPSS. All univariate and multivariate statistics were generated using SPSS procedure commands. Most tables were also produced via the SPSS program, although some tables were built and printed using Microsoft Excel.

div.head: WHAT IS A PARTNERSHIP?
div.p: The first question asked in a telephone interviews was "How would you define the concept 'public/private partnership' in general, and as it applies to your specific situation?" As one might expect, the responses gleaned by this question are quite varied and reflect not only the position of the respondent, in relation to his/her particular partnership, but also his/her personal values and belief system.

As such, some of the responses are very vague while others are so specific that they are almost meaningless when taken out of context. Thus, this work strives to build an interpretable frame of reference from which these data can be examined (Appendix C contains the coded responses).

While analyzing the data collected during the telephone interviews, it became evident that all of the responses could be interpreted and coded to fit into five categories, albeit more loosely in some cases than in others. For these data, some of the definitions given are those that describe "partnerships" in terms of resources being shared, or where an organization or group of organizations from one economic sector donates or transfers resources to agencies or schools from a different economic sector. Another type of definition focuses on partnerships as being a process or series of processes, while a third defines a partnership as a means to an end. The last identifiable category includes those definitions that relate the complexity and ambiguity of the partnership concept. This category demonstrates that some partnerships are so narrowly defined and context specific that global characterizations are inadequate forms of descriptions. A fifth category encompasses all other definitions that do not fit into the prior four previous categories. dictate," and yet another adds, "Equality determines the difference between a partnership and a relationship."
This sharing of resources is sometimes just a part of a bigger, overall process.

Thirteen stakeholders defined a partnership as a process. Sometimes this process is mutually beneficial, other times it is not. One example of this type of definition came from a stakeholder in the Cincinnati partnership; "It is a 'true' partnership. There is mutual trust and shared beliefs." A stakeholder from Flint had a similar definition, "Basically, mutual development of programs. An exchange of services." For these stakeholders, the defining characteristic of a partnership is the process of coming together and working toward goals. However, this process is not always an easy one. As a Cincinnati stakeholders laments, "It's like dancing with a blind date, fraught with dangerous territory and pitfalls...."

For yet other stakeholders, process and sharing resources are not important in defining the concept of partnership. For these stakeholders, there is a formal structure or even a legal foundation that provides the stakeholders with a means to achieve an end.

Whereas to the process-oriented stakeholders the means (a process) is at least as important as the outcome, to these teleological thinkers the means is only as important as the end it produces. With simplicity in mind, a stakeholder comments, "An association with a public entity and a private entity." The general comments from this group are centered on the comprehensiveness and context specificity of Public/Private Partnerships. As a Flint stakeholder comments, "You don't define it because it's seamless." Or "No single definition...no two are alike," as a Cincinnati stakeholder claims. There are four additional definitions that do not fit well into any of the four categories developed above. Appendix C contains the coded transcribed comments for the benefit of the reader.

Contrary to the view that partnerships are only context specific, this work is built upon the presupposition that, in building a model of partnership success, there are identifiable shared characteristics that successful partnerships exhibit. div.head: Chapter Six: Multivariate Statistical Model =========== PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS IN EDUCATION ===========
div.p: In this chapter a model of partnership success is tested using Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression and path analyses. In the first section of this chapter, the hypothesized relationships between the partnership success score and its predictor variables are detailed. The exogenous and endogenous variables are identified and their suggested influences on the dependent variable outlined. Through the use of multivariate regression analysis, the Standardized Beta Weights are calculated and presented for examination.

In the second section of the chapter, a reconstructed model of partnership success is presented by examining the statistically significant regression equations. Each statistically significant exogenous and endogenous predictor variable from the full model is examined in detail with its direct and indirect influences described. The end product of this section is a reduced model of partnership success. This final model is not to be judged on its predictive capability, but, rather, used as a guide in leading the discussion on important Public/Private Partnership characteristics.

The third section of the chapter uses the reduced model to compare the theoretical model of partnership success with the empirical data while making some general statements about the success components.

As a precursory note to this chapter, the author acknowledges that there are many assumptions of OLS that must be realized if the regression coefficients are to be unbiased. Unfortunately, given the many limitations of this work, it is impossible to have a high level of faith that all of these assumptions have been achieved in these data. In addition, correct model specification in partnership analysis mirrors the broader problem manifest in theory development in the social sciences. Thus, this work acknowledges the difficult tasks of measuring multiple dimensions of complicated concepts in a parsimonious fashion. The reduced or trimmed model (Kenny, 1998) analysis employed herein is best seen as a method used to reduce a complex world to a level where meaningful discussion can begin. It is a best attempt at blending theory and data driven analysis without sacrificing theoretical rigor or exploratory flexibility. While judging this methodology the reader must make his or her own decisions concerning the amount of robustness to be found.

div.head: Path Analysis
div.p: Path analysis is a multivariate regression technique that allows the researcher to decompose correlations into direct and indirect effects. The purpose of path analysis is to provide estimates of the magnitude and significance of hypothesized causal relationships between variables. Path analysis is used for both exploratory and confirmatory analyses, depending upon the goals of the researcher. In either case, the investigator uses a series of structural equations to test his/her model against the data (Conner, 2000). The relative sizes of the path coefficients in the output path diagram may tell us which of them is better supported by the data (Lea, 1999).

The assumptions for this OLS procedure are similar to those for regression analysis, and, indeed, path analysis is a special case of regression analysis. Thus, a path coefficient is equal to the correlation when the dependent variable is a function of a single independent variable. The path coefficients in a complex casual model are simply the beta weights from a series of multiple regressions, rather than the correlation from just one single regression (Brannick, 2000).

To proceed with this analysis, it is best to assume that all of the relationships are linear and additive; that the error terms are uncorrelated with the variables and each other; that the causality flows in only one direction; that the variables are measured on an interval scale; and that the variables are measured without error.

The presentation of a path analysis uses a graphical display of the coefficients that measure the relative size and direction of the various effects between variables. This graphical display eases interpretation, as does the use of the standardized beta weight.
Rather than reporting unstandardized beta coefficients that result in the comparison of unequal units, the standardized betas allow the direct comparison of effects.

To begin this path analysis, brief descriptions of the variables are now given. The dependent variable to be used in the first two sections of this chapter is a partnership success score calculated from four questions on the survey. Appendix F shows the question number from the survey, the concept the variable measures, and the question wording.

The first path of influence is through the use of creative solutions in working toward goal attainment, with a hypothesized relationship between active debate about means (Q8) and the use of creative solutions (Q4). This part of the path is not supported. Nor is the path that hypothesizes that the reliance on new and creative solutions (Q4) will positively influence partnership success (DV).

The second indirect path of influence is partially supported by these data. The influence of considering more alternatives to achieve partnership goals (Q9) on partnership success (DV) is not supported, however.

The final indirect path of influence, through functionality or imagination in task completion (Q10), is not supported by these data. The theory predicts that partnerships that actively debate means (Q8) will be more likely to use imagination and process in achieving their goal(s) (Q10). These partnerships are then hypothesized to be more successful (DV) than partnerships that rely on functionality in task completion.

The three variables measuring the effect of a partnership catalyst on partnership success are all hypothesized to have one direct and four indirect influences. These three variables will be addressed simultaneously in this discussion. The first catalyst variable measures the extent to which there were a few instrumental people in bringing the partnership together, rather than many (Q25). It is hypothesized that one, or perhaps a few, dominate visionaries are a greater asset to a partnership than many less influential people. In addition, it is hypothesized that these influential people will be marked by strong leadership abilities as a defining characteristic (Q26), and that these individuals are also distinguished by their role as catalyst in the partnering process (Q27A).

When looking at the paths of direct influences that these variables have on partnership success, these data do not support the hypothesized relationships. The findings are slightly mixed where the indirect paths are concerned, with the data supporting some of the theorized relationships.

Thus, it is hypothesized that the catalyst variables (Q25, Q26, Q27A) will all influence the development of one single, or dominate, goal, rather than many equally important goals. These data show a relationship between the number of instrumental people involved at the beginning of the partnership (Q25) and the number of goals that are important to the partnership. These data suggest that the greater the number of individuals involved, the more goals there will be that are important to the partnership (Q1C). Although perhaps an obvious finding, it is one that can dramatically impact a partnership.

Leadership as a defining characteristic (Q26) and a clearly identifiable catalyst (Q27A) do not have a statistically significant influence on the number of goals that are important to the partnership (Q1C). Nor is there a statistical relationship between the number of goals (Q1C) and the level of partnership success (DV). It is hypothesized that partnerships with one, or only a few, dominant goals will be more successful than those with a multitude of goals. Again, these data do not support this hypothesis.

The model also delineates a relationship between the three catalyst variables (Q25, Q26, and Q27A) and the importance of clear goals exhibited by the partnership (Q2, Q3A). The first of these relationships, that between the number of instrumental people (Q25) and the level of detail given to goal discussion, is supported by these data with partnerships having more people involved also having more discussion about goals.
This finding has a substantive, as well as a statistical, significance and will be detailed in greater length in the discussion section of this chapter.

The level of leadership as a defining characteristic (Q26) is not supported by these data as having an influence on the amount of discussion given to goals (Q2). An identifiable catalyst (Q27A), however, is supported. This relationship is statistically significant and indicates that when an identifiable catalyst is present, the goals of the partnership are more likely to be discussed in detail (Q2).

Of the three catalyst variables, only an identifiable catalyst (Q27A) is a good predictor of a partnership having an overall mission statement (Q3A). These data indicate that those partnerships with an identifiable catalyst are also those with mission statements. The number of instrumental people (Q25) and leadership as defining characteristic (Q26) are not good predictors of this variable.
The level of discussion concerning goals at the beginning of the partnership (Q2)

is not a good predictor of partnership success (DV). Although the existence of a goal or mission statement (Q3A) is statistically significant, these data show the relationship is in the opposite direction of the one hypothesized. Thus, these data indicate that partnerships without an overall goal or mission statement (Q3A) are more likely to succeed (DV)

These data, however, do support the hypothesis that partnerships that discuss goals in greater detail (Q2) and partnerships that have an overall mission or goal statement (Q3A) are more likely to have goal(s) that are more measurable (Q20). In addition, the hypothesis that partnerships that have more measurable goals (Q20) are more likely to succeed (DV) is, in turn, supported by these data.

The data also support the hypothesis that partnerships with more measurable goals (Q20) are also more likely to be fruitful in achieving their goals (Q21). These same partnerships, i.e., those achieving their goals, then, are likely to be more successful (DV)
in their overall partnership endeavor.
This model also hypothesizes that partnerships that rely more on visioning than relying on a concrete plan in achieving their goals (Q5) have a greater chance to succeed.

These data are of no assistance in confirming this hypothesis. A similar situation exists where these data produce findings that are not statistically significant when testing the hypothesis that partnerships that follow a strategy in achieving their goals are more successful than those that react to internal change (Q6).

Separate, but related, to the existence of a guiding goal or mission statement is the type of statement that a partnership uses. Written statements are more formal, and, thus, more institutionalized than less formal verbal agreements. This model posits that a more formal statement (Q3C) will result in greater partnership success. These data do not support this hypothesis.

Three other hypotheses concerning goal development are also not supported by these data. First, it is hypothesized that partnerships that design goals to achieve a practical vision for the future are more likely to succeed (DV) than partnerships that design goals in reaction to internal changes (Q7). Second, partnerships that have clear goals are posited to be more successful than those partnerships that do not (Q1A).

Finally, partnerships that have some flexibility in the day to day practice of goal achievement are hypothesized to have a greater chance of succeeding than those partnerships that try to rely on specific policies for every situation (Q11).

The next variables are those that measure the level of uncertainty a partnership faces, and how partnerships deal with that uncertainty. The set also includes variables that measure the amount of support that exists in the community for the partnership.

One of the most fundamental aspects of any partnership is the environment in which it exists. This model theorizes that, all things considered, partnerships that exist in simple environments will have a greater chance at succeeding. These data support several hypotheses built around this theory but fail to support others.

As the Table 5-1 shows, one hypothesis posits that partnerships that exist in simple external environments (Q13) are more likely to face lower levels of internal uncertainty (Q15) than those partnerships existing in complex environments. This hypothesis is supported by these data.

The next two hypotheses are extensions of the previous ones. Thus, partnerships with low levels of internal uncertainty (Q15) are hypothesized to cope better with the uncertainty they face by adapting (Q17), and, those that adapt to uncertainty (Q17) are more likely to succeed (DV). The data support both of these claims.

In a set of corollary hypotheses, partnerships that exist in a simple external environment (Q13) are hypothesized to face lower levels of external uncertainty (Q16), and, thus, will have little trouble coping with uncertainty through adaptation (Q17).
Again, these data support this set of hypotheses.

Internal (Q15) and external (Q16) uncertainties are also hypothesized to influence the internal relationships of a partnership (Q14). These data support the hypotheses that lower levels of internal uncertainty (Q15) and external uncertainty (Q16) will result in greater stability in the internal relationships of the partnership (Q14). This higher level of relationship stability (Q14), however, is not supported by these data as increasing a partnership's likelihood of success (DV).

Several variables are hypothesized to influence community perception, and, thus, partnership success. Media support (Q28A) is hypothesized to have a positive impact on community perception (Q24) with the media being willing and able to inform community members about the partnership's efforts. This hypothesis is supported by these data.

Community support (Q29A) is also hypothesized to influence community perception. Thus, it is hypothesized that community individuals, or small groups of individuals such as clergy or teachers, will have a positive impact on community perception through their activities and dissemination. This hypothesis is not supported by these data.

A few instrumental people (Q25) can often be vocal and help influence community perception (Q24) through their actions, a hypothesis that is not supported by these data. However, strong leadership (Q26) and a partnership catalyst (Q27A) both have a positive influence on community perception, as confirmed by these data.

The influence of positive community perception (Q24) on partnership success is supported by these data with those partnerships reporting good perceptions also reporting greater levels of partnership success.

div.head: Reconstruction Of The Model
div.p: As Figure 6-2 shows the reconstructed paths of influences with the recalculated standardized beta weights and their levels of statistical significance. The reader will notice that as the model is simplified in this reconstruction process, the influence of a partnership having a goal or mission statement looses its level of statistical significance.
This change is noted in the figure by a lack of bold typeface in the reported statistic.

In addition, the reader will notice the two paths located at the bottom of the figure. These paths show that although the variables have no influence on partnership success (DV), per se, they do have a span of influence. Thus, these data support the hypothesis that partnerships that have a more active debate about means to achieve their goal(s) (Q8) are also more likely to consider more alternatives in working toward those goals (Q9). They also support the claim that partnerships that have one or two instrumental people bringing the partnership together (Q25) will also have one or two dominant goals (Q1C). Substantive comments about these, and the rest of the statistical model findings, are reserved for the discussion section of this chapter. Moving from left to right and starting at the top of Figure 6-2, the graphic shows that when there are only a few key people in a leadership capacity brining the partnership together (Q25) there is less discussion of the goals of the partnership (Q2) than when there are many influential people (.133/.016). The data support a similar finding with respect to the presence of a catalyst in the partnership. Thus, when there is a catalyst (Q27A) present, these data indicate that there is a greater propensity for partnerships to discuss their goals (Q2) (.151/.016).

Furthermore, these data support the hypothesis that partnerships that have an active stakeholder (catalyst) advocating their work (Q27A) are more likely to have an overall goal or mission statement (Q3A). Both the level of goal discussion and the existence of a mission statement are hypothesized to influence the degree to which a partnership's goals are measurable. These data support both of these hypotheses.

Partnerships that discuss their goal(s) in greater detail (Q2) are likely to have more measurable goal(s) (Q20) (.287/.000) as are partnerships with mission statements (Q3A) (.129/.020) . The direct path of influence of an overall mission or goal statement (Q3A)
on partnership ceases to be statistically significant in the reconstructed model.

The model continues, from left to right, with the path that demonstrates the hypothesis that partnerships with more measurable goals (Q20) are more likely to achieve their goal(s) (Q21). These data strongly support this hypothesis (.387/.000). These data also support the hypothesis that partnerships that are successful in achieving their goal(s) (Q21) are also more likely to be politically successful (.455/.000).

The type of external environment in which a partnership exists has several paths of influence on its political success. As Figure 5-2 demonstrates, partnerships that exist in a simpler external environment (Q13) are less likely to face both internal uncertainty (Q15) (.309/.000) and external uncertainty (Q16) (.270/.000).

Internal and external uncertainty, in turn, have their own paths of influence on other variables. The amount of internal uncertainty a partnership faces (Q15) has an influence on its ability to cope with that uncertainty (Q17). Partnerships exhibiting lower levels of uncertainty cope better than those with higher levels (-.245/.000). It also influences the internal relations among the partnership stakeholders. Thus, partnerships with lower levels of internal uncertainty (Q15) are more likely to have stable internal relations among stakeholders (Q14) (.204/.001).

The same influences are true for external uncertainty, with partnerships having low levels of external uncertainty (Q16) better able to cope with the uncertainty they face (Q17) (-.166/.005). These partnerships are also more likely to have greater stability in their internal relations among partnership stakeholders (Q14) (.207/.001).

These data also support the hypothesis that partnerships that cope with uncertainty (Q17) are also more successful (.136/.004). In addition, partnerships that cope with uncertainty (Q17) are also more likely to have greater stability in the internal relations among stakeholders. It must be pointed out that although stable internal relations are no doubt important to partnerships, these data do not support the hypothesis that there is any direct influence on partnership success. In this reconstructed model, the reader will note this path is not statistically significant at the .05 level and therefore excluded from Figure 5-2.

Turning to the last set of theoretical paths, the model addresses some of the factors from the environment. The media's importance in the success of public/private partnerships in education is supported by these data. Thus, the media has an indirect influence of partnership success through several paths.

Again referencing Figure 5-2 and moving from left to right, the media is seen to influence community perception, with partnerships having the support of the media (Q28A) more likely to have a positive community image (Q24) (.141/.012). Partnerships that have a champion(s) that exhibits leadership as a defining characteristic (Q26) are more likely to have a positive community image (Q24) (.110/.049), as are those that have an identifiable catalyst (Q27A) (.111/.049).

These data support the hypothesis that community perception is important to the political success of public/private partnerships in education. Thus, partnerships with more positive images are more likely to be those partnerships that are successful (.214/.000) in their partnering endeavors.

This discussion now turns to looking at the general findings supported by these data and the implications of these findings for partnerships. This chapter concludes by addressing topics for future research in public/private partnerships in education.

Tables 6-1 through 6-5 displays the findings from the above analysis by the partnership dimension (page 2-17) measured. As The existence of a mission or goal statement (Q34) also influences the degree to which goals are measurable (Q20). Although the influence is not as strong (.129), these data support the theory that partnerships that are focused enough to have such a statement are also going to have measurable goals.

The data also support the theory that partnerships with more measurable goals (Q20) are also going to achieve those goals (Q21). This finding is moderate in statistical strength (.387) and is one of the two strong relationships to come from these data. The other strong relationship is the one between achieving partnership goals (Q21) and partnership success (DV/.455). This finding is not only supported by these data, but confirms to the theory of partnership success posited by this work. Conversely, partnerships struggling to achieve their goals are going to face a much tougher road to success.

Table 6-2 summarizes the findings from the data concerning the ability of partnerships to adapt to their external and internal environments. As the theory on page 2-18 details, this dimension can be thought of as rigidity ---flexibility. These data do an adequate job of supporting this theory.
Hence, these data clearly demonstrate that the complexity of the external environment in which a partnership exists can have multiple effects on that partnership.

First, the complexity of the external environment influences the level of internal uncertainty that a partnership faces. Among the detriments of having to face high levels of internal uncertainty is strain, and drain, on people and resources. Most partnerships cannot spare the resources to deal with such uncertainty, and would rather focus their scarce resources on achieving their goals.

The external environment (Q13) also influences the level of external uncertainty (Q16) a partnership faces, although the effect is not as strong (.270) as it is on internal uncertainty (Q15/.309). As with internal uncertainty, this observation indicates that partnerships existing in complex environments are going to see a strain on resources as they struggle to achieve their goals and cope with external uncertainty. Partnerships that face lower levels of internal and external uncertainty do a better job of dealing with uncertainty (Q17). There is some difference in the influence that internal and external uncertainty have on this ability with internal uncertainty (Q15/-.245) having a greater impact than external uncertainty (Q16/-.166).

The levels of both internal and external uncertainty influence the stability of internal partnership relations. The effects of these two variables are very similar on stability (Q14), with external uncertainty (Q16) exerting a slightly greater influence than internal uncertainty (Q15/.207, .204, respectively).
Table 6-3 show the significant findings from the third theoretical dimension, the ability of the partnership to approach achieving their goals with a degree of broad vision.

Having a mission or vision statement (Q3A) has a small influence on partnerships having measurable goals (Q20/.129). It seems reasonable to expect partnerships that place time, effort, and commitment to the development of a mission statement to also devote resources to designing goals that are measurable.
Likewise, the data show that partnerships that actively debate the means to achieve their goals (Q8) are also more likely to consider more alternatives (Q9/.414).

Although this finding has no direct statistical influence on partnership success, it certainly can have a substantive impact on the practice of partnering. Hence, for those partnerships that are subject to political scrutiny, the process of alternative development The number of instrumental people involved at the beginning of a partnership (Q25) has multiple influences on the partnership dynamic. With more people involved, there is more discussion about the goals of the partnership (Q2/-.133). Although this relationship is not a strong one, the data do support the notion that involving more stakeholders up front is one way to avoid groupthink.

Conversely, the data also show that the more people that are involved (Q25) the more goals (Q1C) there will be that are important to the partnership (.116). Thus, partnerships can be faced with a dilemma. Although increasing the number of stakeholders is good in terms of discussing the details of the goals, it also increases the number of goals that become important to the partnership. The theory posited in this model predicts that increasing the number of goals will hurt a partnership's chance for political success. These data do not support this path of the model, however. Leadership has an indirect influence on partnership success via community perception, according to these data. Hence, partnerships that have an advocate that exhibited leadership as a defining characteristics are more likely to have more positive images in their broader communities.

An individual, or a small group of individuals, also have a statistical influence on partnership success. Those partnerships that can identify such a catalyst are more likely to discuss partnership goals, have a mission or goal statement, and to have a positive community image. Of the these three direct influences, the strongest is on having a goal or mission statement. Clearly, the role of catalyst is an important one that is multidimensional.
Table 6-5 shows the two paths from the popular support dimension that are statistically significant.

Thus, those partnerships that glean strong positive image in the community are more likely to be successful in their efforts. In addition, those partnerships that gain the support of the media are those more likely to garner the support of the community.
Although neither of these paths are strong, these data do support the claim that these relationships are important components of the partnering process.

div.head: Chapter Seven: Implications and Conclusions ========== PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS IN EDUCATION =========
div.p: Over the last twenty years or so the business community has taken a renewed interest in public education. Prior to the release of A Nation At Risk in 1984 (National Commission for Excellence), the private sector had all but completely withdrawn from the education scene that they once dominated in the early part of the last century (Timpane, 1991).

Their reluctance to participate in an political process beyond their span of control was overwhelmed by their dire need for a quality workforce -and, indeed, an increasing incidence of broader social problems that were, and still are, directly and indirectly related to the quality of public education.

One way in which the private sector contributes to the improvement of public education is through partnering activities with school buildings, districts, and broader systems to develop programs, create opportunities, and to lend their expertise to those challenged with the effective and efficient administration of public education.

The literature on Public/Private Partnerships in Education is becoming quite extensive with many works being produced in the field of education. In addition, many not-for-profit and governmental institutes, agencies, and think-tanks have come onto the scene in the last five-to-ten years conducting studies and evaluations and facilitating more effective partnering activities.

Most of these evaluations and studies belong in the category of "best practices" and provide existing and potential stakeholders with "how to" lists of actions. However, these works fail to offer empirical support for their best practice claims. The data are non-existent or anecdotal, at best. Another weakness in the body of literature is the lack of solid theory development on what constitutes a successful partnership. This research attempts to make a first cut at addressing these two weaknesses in the literature. To accomplish this task, a critical assumption is made. That is, the view of partnering as a political process is accepted as axiomatic. Not a single work in the literature -as discovered by this author -defines partnering in this way, nor does any work define partnership success as political success. To discover the applicability of these assumptions a model of partnership success is constructed and tested. Although the analytic path analysis supports several of the hypothesized paths, it is important to the overall intent of this research to move beyond the mere statistical significance and to recall the substantive relevance of the overall findings. This dual emphasis on statistical and substantive significance reasserts the importance of the theoretical model developed in the first three chapters. Seeing the big picture or adopting a global perspective of the partnering process requires returning to the descriptive findings detailed in chapter three Hence, the path model's strength is in identifying the statistically significant relationships that may be generalized to the broader partnership population. It is not adequate, however, for communicating the importance of several key model elements of the partnership process. Recalling the findings from the stakeholder interviews reinforces the notion of partnering as a process. Thus, with the qualitative data in mind, it takes very little effort to see the validity in arguing that the partnership process is the embryonic sack that nourishes the identified theoretical components. In a vein similar to that argued by Kingdon (1984), the six elements or "streams" must come together during a window of opportunity. An opportunity created by the partnering process.

Where this theory of partnership success diverges from Kingdon's (1984) work, however, is in the rejection of an orthogonal relationship between elements and in the acceptance of the non-predictive emergent nature of Public/Private Partnerships in Education. Thus, the identified elements are not completely independent of the other elements, and, indeed, share many non-recursive pathways. This research began by asking: "How well do the data fit the model of Partnership Success?" In terms of the analytic path model, overall these data do not fit as well as expected. Thus, only a few of the hypothesized paths are statistically significant at the 0.05 level, and, when comparing the bi-variate correlations to the total effects of the direct and indirect paths, these data do not support the model to a strong degree. With these limitations in mind, however, it is important to stress that several parts of the model are supported by these data and that this is the first empirical work testing many claims held as 'common sense' by partnership practitioners and scholars alike. Given a theoretical structure too complex to test with one statistical model and a data set with a limited number of variables, what conclusions can be drawn at the metaanalytic level? Again, the univariate findings become important. Thus, although the global model suffers from a modest deficit of explanatory power, there are numerous findings that are of statistical and/or substantive significance. In addition, these findings prove useful in better understanding what success of a Public/Private Partnership in Education means, and the contributing factors to that success. In the following paragraphs, the findings from the three data analyses are weighed against the research questions to determine the value of this research.

div.head: Success Of Partnerships
div.p: The second set of research questions concerns "Partnership Success:" how partners define it, how successful their partnerships are, and how likely stakeholders are to continue to participate in their partnerships or in future partnerships. These data indicate that stakeholders are very committed to their partnerships and will continue to participate.

In an unexpected finding, these data show that the partnerships represented in this work are mature partnerships and that there is a lack of variability in some of the critical measures. One reason for this lack of variability in the key variables is the high degree of maturity exhibited by the partnerships sampled for this research. Thus, the average age of partnerships responding to the mail survey is approximately five years (mean=5 years/median=5.5 years). This high degree of maturity indicates that these partnerships are, indeed, successful according to the political definition posited by this work.

Thus, although the analytic path model has mixed results in predicting a global model of success, it is important to note that the univariate findings suggest that continued participation and participation in future partnerships are important to the stakeholders responding to the mail survey. In addition to the near consensus of continued participation, the univariate findings also show that these respondents rate their partnerships as successful and are satisfied with their levels of success.
Given the maturity level and the continued success of these partnerships, this work's descriptive findings may be interpreted and used as an empirically based "best practices" for partnering.

In addition to these univariate findings, when analyzing the phone interview data and open-ended question from the mail survey, there is a high degree of consensus on what partners mean by success. Stakeholders relate that their partnerships must be more focused on outcomes and achieving the goals established by the partnership. This emphasis on achieving measurable goals is not only good news for those who evaluate partnerships, but for all stakeholders, funders, and participants concerned with partnerships in education.

As detailed in the early chapters of this work, greater emphasis on accountability and performance are becoming key tenants for those individuals and institutions that fund and support Public/Private Partnerships in Education. These data show that partnerships are receiving the message and are focusing on tying programs to measurable outcomes.

This changing emphasis has two consequences for partnerships. Thus, program design and evaluation will be more productive endeavors with built-in feed back mechanisms relating outcomes to interventions.

Second, along with greater efficacy in programs due to strengthened logic models, partnerships will also benefit from greater political success. Thus, these data indicate that stakeholders like to participate in successful partnerships -those that have achieved measurable goals. The lesson for less mature partnerships is that by emphasizing outcomes and goal achievement, partnerships increase their political viability as well as facilitate more powerful evaluations. Perhaps this last benefit is an obvious finding to an outside perspective, but it is also one often loss on key stakeholders involved in partnering processes.

The model tested herein posits that success is a function of six partnering elements. The following paragraphs describe the important findings concerning the importance of goals, the interaction with the environment, the role of visioning as a means to an end, the role of leadership, and the importance of support and a stabilizing agent.

div.head: Goals And How To Achieve Them
div.p: These data show that there is a high level of congruency between the literature and the participating stakeholders on the important role of goals on partnership success.

Thus, an overwhelming percentage of these stakeholders report that having clear goals is an on-going benefit to their partnership. In addition, deliberation over goals and how to achieve those goals is a common trait of the partnerships represented by the participants.

The reconstructed pathways in the statistical model only partially support the hypothesis that clear goals have an affect on partnership success. Although there is no influence of clear goals on success, other "goal" variables have direct and indirect effects. Clear goals lead to more measurable goals, which, in turn, influence if the goals are achieved. This last path is very important to partnerships since the ability to achieve goals has a very strong influence on partnership success.

Hence, it is important for partnerships give forethought to the types of goals set by the partnership and to think about how those goals can be operationalized for an effective evaluation. This last comment relates to how partnerships know that their goals have been achieved. An unmeasured variable missing from this work is how partnerships know when they have achieved their goals.

This achievement of goals is most likely easier to identify when the goals are clear cut and simplistic. However, not all goals will fit into such a category and it then becomes important to understand how partnerships will know goal achievement has
occurred. One answer is to encourage all partnerships to engage in continuous evaluation either conducted in-house or by an out side evaluator.

The general point, however, is that partnerships must start early in defining what it is they want to achieve and define how they are going to get there. Although this type of deliberation has costs and can frustrate the "action" oriented type of partner, in the long run the benefits are clear to the partnership.

In terms of the focus of the partnership, the univariate data provided mixed support for the theory. A vast majority of the respondents relate their use both tried and true methods and the development of new solutions. The theoretical foundation suggests that creative solutions are a trait associated with greater levels of success. There are two possible interpretations of this disconnect. On one hand, the theory may need revision, or, on the other hand, perhaps the partnerships represented by the stakeholder sample could benefit from such a creative process. Given the dichotomy of the two possibilities, it seems this situation is best addressed by future investigation.

div.head: Partnership Environments
div.p: The day-to-day realities of administering a partnership manifest in the measures of partnership adaptability and flexibility. A clear majority of stakeholders report dealing with internal and external uncertainty, but at the same time their partnerships are reported to be coping well. This finding is consistent with the initial premise that partnerships that adapt well to their environments are those that will be more successful.

These data present a fair amount of variation in the type and degree of uncertainty that partnerships face on a day-to-day basis. These participants report facing various levels of complexity, levels of internal and external uncertainty, and abilities in coping with that uncertainty.

Only one path from this set of variables has a direct influence on partnership success, and this influence is weak. The ability of a partnership to cope with uncertainty has a direct influence, although other variables have indirect influences. It must be noted, however, that these data indicate that other dynamics are at work in partnership space.

Thus, although they have very little influence on partnership success, the reconstructed model shows that the variables of environment, internal uncertainty, and external uncertainty do affect the ability of a partnership to cope with uncertainty, as well as influencing its internal relations.

The lack of support by these data for the theorized relationships is an unsuspected finding of this research, and requires a few comments. First, one possible reason for this lack of empirical support, assuming the underlying theory is sound, is that this model of success is miss-specified. Clearly, it is difficult to model highly complex relationship like those found in partnership space. A second explanation is that there may be a high degree of measurement error. This error is also a distinct possibility given the complexity of the concepts under consideration. Multiple measures of a single concept may produce more robust results. Third, the possibility also exists that the theory is incorrect and these relationships have no influence on partnership success.
At this point, it is impossible to know which of the alternatives is most plausible.
In the future, competing models incorporating different measures may be built and tested
to answer this question.

div.head: The Role of Visioning
div.p: It is clear from these data that the current climate in the partnerships represented by this sample is one that stresses the importance of mission/vision statements. A vast majority of the participants report having such documents and rate them as precise statements rather than vague ones. Thus, these data indicate that such statements not only serve as a rallying point for the partnership, but bring a level of focus to the partnership, as well.

In addition, the path analysis supports the hypothesis that having a mission or vision statement has an influence on measurable goals, and thus, an indirect effect on partnership success. These data also support the theory that the level of debate over the means to achieve the vision influences the number of alternatives considered. As with the paths noted above, although this last path of influence has no direct or indirect effect on partnership success, as measured, it has relevance to the study of partnering.

The process of debating means and of considering alternatives has an unmeasured role in partnering efforts. Often in the world of stakeholders, getting people to the table is a major struggle in and of itself. To attract new stakeholders and build partnership power it becomes necessary to open the floor to new ideas. These ideas are not always good, and sometimes the effort proves frustrating, but the process is as important as the immediate outcome. These data hint at this importance.

div.head: Leadership and Advocacy
div.p: The univariate data overwhelmingly supports the hypothesis that a partnership advocate is a critical element is developing a successful partnership. These stakeholders reported in great majorities that there are only a few instrumental people involved early in the partnering process. In addition, leadership is a defining characteristic of these individuals and they act as an important catalyst to get the partnership up and running.

Human assets are as important to partnering as one suspects. These data support the common sense hypothesis that leadership is a defining characteristic of those individuals reported to be instrumental in the development of partnerships.

The literature is rich with advice and methods to develop strong leadership skills, so there is no reason to belabor the point. From this work, however, it is not clear that leadership is directly associated with successful partnering. The importance of a charismatic leader to an organization is unquestioned, but very few leaders have this trait, and even fewer partners have such a leader.

What these data support is the notion that effective leaders make differences to the success of their partnerships in small ways. From acting as a catalyst in forming the partnership, to working in and with the community to build strong ties, and in facilitating the development of goals and means, it is effective leaders who make partnerships happen.

As a partnership leaves its infancy and starts to coalesce into a routinized operation, the theory of success holds that a stabilization agent will come to the forefront of the partnership to provide a new style of leadership. These data support this claim with eight-in-ten stakeholders identifying at least some change in key personnel. In addition nine-in-ten relate that one single individual can be identified as a having a stabilizing effect on the partnership. Finally, nine-in-ten report that the one identified individual or group is important to the success of the partnership.

It is theorized that once the partnership is in motion, the media play an important role in building popular support and that this popular support is extremely important to the political success of the partnership. Theses descriptive data fully support this contention. A majority of stakeholders report the media playing an important role in forming support for the partnership. In addition, there is almost unanimity in the belief that the community's perception of the partnership is important to its success.
Attention is now turned to the future and the presentation of some topics for greater in-depth research.

div.head: Potential Future Investigation
div.p: The findings from this investigation raise as many questions as they answer.

Although these data present some compelling insights into the political success of Public/Private Partnerships in Education the door has only been set ajar, and much opportunity exists for future work. These opportunities fit into two themes, each addressed briefly in the following paragraphs.

First, the fact that there is no single definition of partnering opens a wide range of possibilities. Care should be taken, however, in any endeavor that might investigate the possibility of developing a standardized definition. Efforts should balance the benefits of having such a standard against the costs of restricting inclusion of the great diversity that exists in the partnering world.

Second, the opportunity exists to narrow the scope of this work into its component pieces for a more detailed look. Each of the six dimensions addressed in this work could easily support individual research. An overarching task, then, is to look at greater model specificity and how the individual components work.
For instance, there is an opportunity to work with existing and potential partnerships in developing their goals in a fashion which facilitates achieving those goals.

What are common goals across partnerships and can these goals be standardized? A standard goal will assist evaluators in developing a set of measures that will inform the partnership that their goal has been achieved. They also allow partnerships to spend less time reinventing the wheel and more time to "cherry pick" the goals that best suit their mission.

Another opportunity exists to study internal and external uncertainties and how partnerships adapt to their environments. As a hybrid organization, the many questions asked of other organizational forms now find new relevance in the education arena.

Greater measurement of how goals and vision interact is another opportunity, as is the related topic of the difference between synergy and entropy and the role of leadership in a partnership. A specific model incorporating these variables would prove very useful in understanding why some partnerships are more successful than others are.

Future work should also entail looking at an enhanced model of success using each of the success measures as dependent variables. Although the scale measure used in this work is a more robust measure of success, these data suggest that each component should be analyzed separately to see if the independent variables have different spheres of influence on the autonomous measures.

div.head: Concluding Remarks
div.p: As a first attempt to build and test an empirical model of Public/Private Partnerships In Education, this research has produced some interesting results. Although not all of the findings are what the model predicts, the overall results prove very useful in bringing about a greater understanding of the partnership process.

In addition, these data support most of the theorized relationships and the reconstructed model shows that numerous paths to success are statistically significant. In attempting to model success, this work has also opened the door to future research in a policy area that has not been exposed to typical levels of analytic rigor by those in the policy sciences.

Researching complex policy topics requires high levels of abstraction and precise measurement -two goals that are often difficult to achieve. Yet, if the study of successful Public/ Private Partnerships In Education is to move beyond the anecdotal and best practices stage, it is important to meet these goals.
